DEPARTMENT OF MINES AND RESOURCES

REQUISITION FOR SUPPLIES File No. 138-7-S

December 14, 1943

To The Departmental Purchasing Agent, Ottawa,

PLEASE FURNISH THE FOLLOWING SUPPLIES FOR USE OF Guy Indian Residential School

VOTE 76 Allotment 09-628 12-415

SHIP TO Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I., Principal, Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Sask., via Atik, Man.

Purpose for which required

NOTE: Requisition for non-consumable equipment, state if New Issue or Replacement. Consumable equipment and supplies use columns 1 and 2.

| Quantity | Quantity on hand (1) | Quantity used previously (2) | Unit Price | TOTAL |
|----------|----------------------|-------------------------------|------------|-------|
| 1        |                      |                               |            |       |
| Brace for Gurney Oxford Stove | | | | |
| 40       |                      |                               |            |       |
| Sq. yds. heavy-weight oilcloth | | | | |

Note: Regarding the request for a brace for the inside of the stove, the Agent writes as follows:

"The top of the range is dropping badly owing to a brace inside the top being broken. The range is a Gurney Oxford made by the Gurney Foundry Co. The number on the stove is No. 2030 F. Name on oven door "John Bull". The brace has no number but it is underneath the stove and next to the firebox to the right at one face the stove. I believe there is nothing on the stove to indicate this. We would like this to be ordered and sent to the Guy Indian Residential School, Atik, Man."

The heavy-weight oilcloth is required to cover the tables in the children's dining room. This is necessary for sanitary reasons.

I hereby certify that I have personal knowledge that all the above articles are required in the Department and for Departmental purposes only. The expenditure required by this requisition is strictly unavoidable and the public interest will suffer if it is not made.

SIGNED

APPROVED

Director

(SEE OTHER SIDE)

Memorandum:

Mr. R. A. Hoey,
Supt., Welfare & Training,
Indian Affairs Branch.

We received this morning a communication from The Gurney Foundry Company, Ltd., P.O. Box 277, Montreal, Que., which reads as follows:

"We have your order 50669-15-2-S-2166 of December 16th covering a brace for a 205-CP Range.

As we are unable to determine from the description you have given us exactly what is wanted, we would ask you to let us have a rough pencilled sketch of the part wanted. When this is received we will be able to supply you with the required repair part."

Will you please arrange to supply the Company with the sketch of the brace for the range at the Guy Indian Residential School.

H.J. Davidson
H. J. Davidson,
Dept. Purchasing Agent.

AIR MAIL

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Man.

I desire to refer to your letter of the 7th ultimo, requesting a brace for the inside of the kitchen range. An order was placed with the Gurney Foundry Company Limited, P.O. Box 277, Montreal, Quebec, but they state that they are unable to determine from the description exactly what is wanted.

Please arrange with the Principal to forward a rough pencil sketch of the part wanted to the firm at the address mentioned above. As soon as this is done the firm will arrange to supply what is required.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Dear Father Plourde:

With reference to your telephone conversation, I believe we can provide approximately $200.00 for the purchase of paint for the Guy School. Please let me know immediately what is required, in order that purchase may be made from the current year's vote.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Rev. J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.,
Ottawa University,
Laurier Ave. East,
Ottawa, Ont.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

In further reference to the request of the Principal of the Guy Residential School for paint for interior decorating, I wish to inform you that you may ship 60 gallons of ready-mixed white paint in five-gallon cans, half flat and half ordinary paint. You may add five gallons of turpentine to the above if the amount which you have on hand will suffice for the two lots.

Thanking you in anticipation, I remain,

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

In reply to your letter 132-7-5, dated the 8th instant, I beg to advise that accounts covering orders No. 21611 and No. 21612 for merchandise for Guy School, have not yet been received in this office.

S. Lovell,

May 31, 1944.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Man.

I have your letter of the 23rd instant, with reference to your voucher No. 785.

On checking this voucher it was found that freight had to be allowed and there were other adjustments in the account which made the correct amount due the firm $23.10, instead of $22.89 as shown on your voucher. Cheque 1506 for $23.10 was forwarded to the Gurney Foundry Company on May 13.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Potato Peeler - Guy Indian Residential School.

The Rev. Poirier, O.M.I., has requested that they be supplied with a potato peeler. He points out that there is altogether too much work for the pupils. The potato peeling, dishwashing and scrubbing is just straight labour and takes too much time away from their studies. The classroom takes half the time and the balance is spent in the laundry, kitchen and in sewing and mending. He points out there is very little time for recreation, and some of the drudgery work should be eliminated.

If a potato peeler is available, I think the request should be granted.

Dear Sir,

I am sorry to say that our lighting plant batteries are run down and that they cannot do another year; in fact I do not see how they can do until next fall. Though they were evidently declining, I did not say anything before because they had a 7-year guarantee dating from March 1940, but it is clear now that we will need a new set of batteries to start the next school year. And as the transport is so much easier by the winter roads, I ask you to try and get them for us within a month to Atik. I know this is a very short time for everything to go through Ottawa, and the manufacture and back here, but, since you are aware of our transport problem in summer, I trust that you will do your best to obtain what I am asking for.

The set of batteries that we are using now is described thus on the invoice from Mumford, Medland Limited, Winnipeg, Mar. 8, 1940:

"I Set Globelite Storage Batteries (for power-plant), GD-15, 200 Ampere hour (intermittent rating) 56 cells, 15 plates (5-3/4" X 7") per cell, 110 volt, 7 year guarantee."

All these batteries are charged and discharged in series. I do not think we could come back on the company because the batteries fail 1 year before the guarantee, because I would be unable to prove that the batteries have always received the proper care, due especially to the emplacement of the machine room under the water tank, which has been leaking badly so often.

Thanking you in advance for your cooperation,

Yours truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Principal.
The Pas, Manitoba,
March 14, 1946.

Dept. of Mines & Resources,

In the last paragraph of his letter, he refers to the machine room roof, which was leaking badly. I beg to advise that this roof was fixed last summer, and at the present time, is in first-class condition.

Your obedient servant,

Re: Diesel stationery engine for Guy School.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

The principal of the Guy Indian Residential School has had considerable difficulty for the last several years in the operation of the steam engine which is now used to supply electricity and general electric power for his school.

Among other complaints he lists the following:
(1) The engine is not powerful enough to do the work properly.
(2) Wood is getting more costly every day and the distance between the school and the forest is lengthening all the time.
(3) It is almost impossible to find or secure a steam-engineer in such a far away place.
(4) The running costs of a steam engine have considerably increased for the last several years because of the long working hours of the engineer who, during all the winter, has to be on duty from 8 a.m. to 9.30 p.m. and cannot do any other work during that period.

It has to be admitted that a diesel would be safer and at least as dependable. The size of the engine required is said to be 20-25 H.P. as it has to operate the dynamo, the water pump, the laundry machinery, the bread-mixer, etc. I admit that the purchase of this motor constitutes quite a heavy expense, but I think nevertheless that it ought to be approved as Sturgeon Landing is situated quite a distance from the railroad and civilization as well, and it is very difficult to secure proper and experienced help for steam engine operation.

Thanking you in anticipation I remain,

Very truly yours,

J.O. Plourde, O.M.I.

ATIK, Manitoba.

Dear Sir,

re Barn water system

We have received through you during this winter the required piping to replace the whole pipe that takes the water underground between the school building and the stable. Would you please mention in your answer what wages could be paid for that kind of work. Since the price of everything is rapidly going up, I suppose that wages too are rising.

We shall have to wait quite a while yet before starting since the ground is still frozen down below.

June 10, 1926.

Sir,

I beg to advise you that you have been appointed Inspector of Construction for the completion of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Sask., at a salary of $6.00 per day, and I am sending you herewith diary sheets which should be kept in duplicate and forwarded to Indian Agent Waddy, who will issue the necessary voucher for the payment of your salary.

The contract for the building has been awarded to Mr. R. N. Wyatt of Winnipeg, at his tendered price of $92,235.00 and it will be your duty to see that the building is erected in accordance with the plans and specifications, also to submit fortnightly reports to the Department outlining the progress of the work. Certificates for payment on the contract should be issued to the contractor up to 90% of the value of the labour and material in the building, as provided for in the specifications.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Re: Diesel Stationery Engine.

Attention: Mr.F.Phelan.

Dear Sir,

I would like to expose to you a few more details concerning our need of a new stationery engine to replace our old steam engine.

The question was introduced to you by Rev.Father J.O.Plourde in a letter of January the 28th,1947, and,as I was given to understand, the matter was receiving your kind consideration; so I did not insist any more. But we have had to begin another winter with the old equipment, and no sign yet of any development in answer to the letter above mentioned.

THE OLD ENGINE-

Engine specifications: The engine now in use is a 16 H.P. vertical steam engine, cyl 7" diz. by 8" stroke, speed 275 RPM driving belt pulley 20" diz. by 10½" face, shaft dizm. 2½", balance wheel 26" dizm. x 6¾" face. Weight 1500 lbs. The invoice from Mumford Melland Limited, Winnipeg, which contains these details about the engine is dated February 3, 1939.

Installation: The engine was put in place shortly after its arrival,in the spring 1939.

Hours of service: Since about March 1939,that engine has been running an average of 8 hours a day, in weeks of 76-80 hours in winter to weeks of a mere 32-35 hours in summer: a sum of 26,000 hours in 9 years.

Uses: Insufficiency: Every machine in the school depends on that motor: dynamo, water pump, laundry washer and extractor, drier, bread-mixer. When, at times, several machines have to work simultaneously the motor is overloaded and the service is very poor.

Condition and servicing:The engine has not been serviced nor repaired by any outside specialist since its use, but our local engineer always did himself in a very satisfactory way the repairs and adjustments needed. However he is finding it ever more difficult to obtain from it the necessary power, and the oiler, apparently defective from the start, has been giving more than its share of trouble.

Original cost: The invoice bears the price of $191.40, plus tax of 15.31, plus freight prepaid of 69.92, making a total cost of $276.63. N.B.-The engineer who received it here does not believe that this was a new engine.

Cost of wood: No one thinks any more that wood is cheap as long as you live in a bush country. About 300 cords of wood,at $5.00 a cord,go for the high-pressure boiler every year.
Cost of labour: To the cost of fuel must be added the cost of labour. A steam engineer is hard to get, especially in this far-away and isolated place, and needs a good pay; and all the time the engine is running he can do practically no other work. The running cost of the engine is thus increased by the full wages of the engineer.

Danger: The element of danger with a high-pressure boiler in the school basement may well be considered too.

SUMMARY: The wear of the engine, its insufficient power (or at least its actual insufficiency), the cost of wood, the difficulty to secure an engineer, and the high price wood and engineer together mean for each running hour, all this will justify, I think, a change and here is my request:

DIESEL POWER REQUESTED-

Capacity: A 20 to 25 H.P. stationary Diesel motor.

Advantages over the old engine:

- More dependable

- Stronger: would care for the occasional bigger demands of power, and when under less strain would not wear out so quick.

- More economic on fuel.

- More economic on labour: Diesel engine operators are becoming more common, and while in charge of the machines the engineer or operator could also attend to many other jobs.

- Safer.

In view of these advantages, I trust that the Department will consider very seriously this demand and answer it favorably. The question of dependable power in a building of this size which is far from all outside help can not be dealt with lightly, and though I do not disregard the cost of the new engine I am pressed by the circumstances to insist in demanding it.

I believe that the steam engine may take us through this winter, providing the poor health of our actual engineer does not break down. If we get the engine requested, we shall have it installed as soon as arrived, but in all events we strongly beseech you to make haste so that, if sent, it would be in time before the winter freighting is over, in which all heavy material is handled.

Our batteries are good yet, as it is only their second year.

As to the steam boiler itself, which has not been inspected for three years, it could be used yet as steam is needed, though with less pressure, for the laundry on wash days; steam is used also for heating the water pipe leading from the reservoir, and for other smaller uses.

So that is our problem, our biggest problem right now on the material level, as simply as I can put it to you.
The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Re: Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan

In compliance with your notation of March 15th appearing on Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you of the 13th ultimo, we have investigated the situation at the above School and make the following comments:

In our memorandum dated February 9, 1948, we requested further information which was obtained by the Indian Affairs Branch and forwarded in Rev. Principal Poirier's letter dated March 9th along with Mr. Hoey's memorandum. From data contained therein, it appears that they require a new engine to replace the existing steam engine used to drive a power line shaft delivering power to a water pump generator and laundry and baking equipment.

We believe the best solution to the power requirements would be to provide electric motors on each piece of equipment and a power plant to suit, thus eliminating the undesirable feature of line shaft and belt drives.

It is realized, however, that this would be costly in view of existing installed equipment and that considerable time for execution would be required, and as power equipment is urgently needed, we have in our analysis kept to the present system arrangement using existing equipment and suggested new equipment, as outlined in our recommendations, to provide a reliable power and lighting system.

We recommend that a self-contained diesel electric plant be purchased with full automatic control for operation with existing battery bank for the lighting system and a diesel engine for the operation of power shaft line to replace the existing steam engine. With this new equipment, the strain on the shaft line caused by the generator operating a maximum of six hours per day, would be removed and it is likely that the shaft troubles mentioned in Rev. Principal Poirier's letter will not recur. Dear Sir,

It was very gratifying to receive your prompt reply of the 17th instant, offering a 10 KW electric light plant in response to our demand for a Diesel motor.

This electric light plant would surely answer all our needs regarding electricity, but it would not serve the other machines, such as water pump, laundry machinery, etc., unless individual electric motors could be supplied and installed for each machine. This would mean the additional buying of:

- 1 electric motor of 6 h.p. for the water-pump
- 1 " " " 5 h.p. " " bread-mixer
- 1 " " " 2 h.p. " " washer
- 1 " " " 4 h.p. " " extractor

Or if the motor of an electric plant as the one offered had another pulley by which to command other machinery than the dynamo, simultaneously or not, it would be fine too.

Another alternative to this would be one Diesel engine, only the engine, between 20 and 30 h.p., that would simply be put in place of the actual steam engine, though this would also entail the buying of a new and bigger drive shaft, with proportionate bearings.

So, while your present offer does not quite meet our requirements, I shall be very grateful to see you adopt one of the three solutions:

1/ The Onan electric plant, plus the electric motors as indicated.
2/ An electric plant similar to the above, but with another pulley acting as power take-off for other machinery.
3/ A Diesel stationary engine, from 20 to 30 h.p.
June 11, 1948.

Memorandum

Re Gay Indian Residential School,
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

In reply to your marginal notation of June 14 appearing in Mr. Hoey's memorandum of the 11th instant, forwarded to this Division with attached tenders and correspondence in connection with power and lighting equipment for the above school, we make the following comments.

It is noted from Rev. Principal Poirier's letter of May 28th last, in reply to Mr. B.F. Neary's of the 17th instant, that he comments on Indian Affairs offer of providing a 10 KW. lighting plant only, no mention being made of the stationary diesel engine to provide power for the shaft line.

In our memorandum of April 1st last, we suggested and prepared our specifications on the basis of a lighting plant for the electrical loads and a diesel engine to power existing line shaft driving other machinery. In view of the fact that the Rev. Poirier makes no mention of the stationary diesel engine in his comments, it would appear that perhaps Indian Affairs are considering some other means of powering the line shafting to take care of water pump, laundering machinery, etc. Before further consideration is given to the tenders received, we would like the Indian Affairs Branch to advise this Division if they are considering some other means of providing power for mechanical loads in which case we need only concern ourselves with the lighting plant. It should be pointed out, however, that the lighting plant equipment tendered on would not be of sufficient capacity for the operation of lighting and power loads if the electrification of mechanical equipment is under consideration.

Until advice, as indicated above is received, we will retain the tenders forwarded.

Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir,

Since I have answered on May the 28th to your so interesting offer of an electric plant so long desired, I have been expecting every mail to hear more about it.

I have been wondering also if you wouldn't have found me too hard to please.

It may be too that your engineers are actually considering other points and aspects of the project, and enquiring about the plants available.

In any event, I would be very thankful to you to let me know if and what we may hope for in a near future in respect to our power and electric problems.

For a while it looked as if we would be able to change our motor during the summer holidays, when it would less disturb the normal operations; the high water would equally have made easier the transport of a heavy machine by way of a boat on the Saskatchewan River. Now the water is slowly receding but will likely allow that boat to travel all summer.

However to put a new Diesel motor in, we shall not mind going into a lot of trouble at any time and it will be good news to learn it is coming.

Yours very truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Principal;

Mr. Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

Your letter of July the 8th with the attached memorandum was unfortunately missed by the Post Office to Cumberland House and thus arrived in Sturgeon Landing two weeks late.

By that time I had already been enquiring about such information as contained therein. To which enquiry you have also kindly replied. Meanwhile I went away for ten days, and it is only on my return that I have found both your letters of July the 8th and of July the 26th, to which I am sorry to be so late in replying.

The Memorandum of your technical officers is pointing out precisely to the difficulty I was mentioning in my letter of May the 28th, viz. that the electrical plant offered was not providing for the power supply necessary for machines other than the dynamo.

In their own words: "We suggested and prepared our specifications on the basis of a lighting plant for the electrical loads and a diesel engine to power the existing line shaft driving other machinery". In other terms they seem to advise the use of two different motors: one included with a dynamo, which would be the lighting plant already offered in yours of May 17th, and separately, a diesel engine to power the already existing line shaft driving other machinery.

Actually, with the lighting plant already tendered, there is no provision made for the needs other than electric lighting. But the solution proposed by the engineers of having another separate engine to drive the line shaft would take care of everything, and I would be most in favor of it because it would save the replacing of the actual shaft and bearings.

I fail to see any other information that they would desire right now, but I will make it a point to answer immediately any further enquiry that may arise, since this power question is a vital one to the school.

Yours very truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,

Memorandum

Re: Guy Indian Residential School,
Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan

In reply to your marginal notation of August 18th appearing on Mr. Hoey's memorandum to you of the 16th instant, we make the following comments and refer you to our memoranda of April 1st, and June 22nd last, in connection with the equipment required for the above school.

It would appear from correspondence forwarded to this Division from Indian Affairs that Reverend Principal Poirier was not furnished with our complete recommendations in connection with the equipment required at the school, when he was asked in a letter dated May 17th last from the Indian Affairs Branch to comment on the proposed new equipment.

Extracts from the Principal's recent letter, quoted in Mr. Hoey's memorandum, indicate that he was fully advised of our proposals in a later letter from the Indian Affairs subsequent to our memorandum of June 22nd. Reverend Principal Poirier concurs in the type of installation we suggested for handling the lighting and mechanical loads at the school, and he realizes that this arrangement will not require replacement of the line shaft.

There appears, judging from the last paragraph of Mr. Hoey's memorandum wherein he remarks about being anxious to "ship in the motor", to be some misunderstanding regarding our proposals, and we would refer Indian Affairs to our memorandum of April 1st last in which we set forth our recommendations in detail.

You are advised that no changes or revisions to our recommendations and specifications are necessary, since conditions at the school are, to our knowledge, unchanged from those existing at the time of our study.

We would point out, however, that April 26th was the closing date given in the Request for Quotations based on our specifications, and we suggest that the tendering firms be contacted to determine if their tender prices and/or delivery dates of equipment offered at that time are still applicable.

We are returning the tenders herewith to assist the Departmental Purchasing Agent in communicating with the tendering firms, but upon receipt of their reply concerning their price, the tenders should be furnished to us for comment.

Encl.

R.A. Gibson, Esq.,
Director,

Department of Mines and Resources,

Dear Sirs:

On August 28th we received a request from the Rev. L. Poirier, of the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan, to send an inspector at the earliest possible date to inspect their boilers which were causing them a good deal of concern. This was followed by a telegram to our Prince Albert Inspector, Mr. M.B. Crook in who's district Sturgeon Landing is situated, to come as early as possible to make the inspection as we had given the Rev. L. Poirier, Mr. Crook's address.

With a good deal of difficulty, Mr. Crook journeyed to Sturgeon Landing to make the inspection and inspected all the boilers. He found that the high pressure boiler had developed a very dangerous condition. This boiler, which was shut down due to a leaking stay-bolt in the water leg was found to be completely blocked with scale in the rear of the boiler and was in parts of the side legs.

Mr. Crook spent the better part of two days assisting one of the Brothers at the school in cleaning the boiler and removing accumulated scale and before he left had the boiler in such condition that it could be operated.

In view of the fact that this inspection was specially requested, we are billing the Department for the out-of-pocket expenses of our inspector in connection with same, in addition to the regular boiler inspection fees. These accounts are enclosed herewith and we shall be pleased to receive payment of same at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

(Signed) Joseph Taylor,
Chief Inspector.

Subject: Requisition No. 77161
File: 15/16 - Your Order 36802

Gentlemen:

The subject order covers one (1) only Fairbanks-Morse Model 48AS4 Diesel Power Unit developing 16 HP at 1200 RPM. This engine is to drive a line shaft at approximately 335 RPM. In our quotation, we included two suitable pulleys for the engine and the line shaft. The specification calls for flat face pulleys 10" in width. We have had correspondence with Reverend L. Poisier, Principal of the Guy Residential School, and he advises that the 10" width has probably been specified because of the fact that 10" pulleys are presently in use. We received information from a supplier that we should furnish 11" pulleys with crown faces and we advised the reverend Poisier accordingly. Upon checking this subject further, we have now learned that 6" belting will be ample in size for this transmission and that 7" pulleys should be provided. We are confident that this latter recommendation will prove most satisfactory.

There are two reasons why we prefer to furnish pulleys 7" in width if acceptable to you. Firstly, we can provide a standard concentric pulley instead of an off-set hub type pulley which would be required if 11" wide. We believe that with the overhanging effect encountered with the 11" pulley in time, it may be possibly prove detrimental to the smooth running of the clutch bearings. Secondly, these pulleys are standard and can be shipped promptly.

If an off-set is required, then it must be made up specially with the consequent delay in delivery. We intend to furnish an ordinarily pulley for the line shaft, assuming that it can be mounted from the end and that a split hub type is not required. If pulleys 7" in width are acceptable, then we would appreciate receiving your confirmation. The belting used for this drive should be medium heavy duty belting. This engine was shipped from the factory on January 14th, so that we would request that you give this subject your immediate attention.

Yours very truly,

F.D. Wolever - Sales Engineer Engine Department
Ottawa, January 31, 1949

Regina, March 11th, 1949.

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

When visiting the Guy Indian Residential School, at Sturgeon Landing, recently, a number of matters were brought to my attention which require quite a large expenditure, and are as follows.

(1) The water supply is furnished by a pump from the river to a gravity tank. This gravity tank may, at any time, go out of order as it is constructed of wood, and the bottom is badly warped. The engine room and laundry are both much too small and the laundry needs a ventilator fan very badly. The school should be enlarged to accommodate 200 children if it is the intention to continue to operate a residential school for that area, which, in my opinion, is desirable. The barn was very badly planned in the first instance, the foundation being about 2 ft. below the ground surrounding the barn, with the result that there is no drainage and the floor of the barn is always wet. I considered the possibility of raising the floor about 6 ft., in order to give drainage. This will be very costly, and I am not sure that it is justified. Perhaps it would be better to build a new barn and dismantle the old one, using as much of the material as possible. All of these matters suggest that an engineer should be sent to that school to examine and report on the various needs, with a view to placing quite a large amount in the Estimates for 1950-51, as I presume there is little hope of getting it done in the coming fiscal year.

(2) This school is under very excellent management and is doing a very fine work. Most of the Indian children attending the school could not be well served by day schools as they come from a very scattered area, consisting mostly of quite small groups, where the livelihood is derived almost entirely from trapping and fishing. A great deal more school accommodation is needed for that area, and I believe that the most economical way to meet this need, at least partly, is by enlarging the Guy School to accommodate 200 pupils.

There is an item in the Estimates for a new day school at Pine Bluff. I enquired into the possibilities there, and I do not recommend a day school at that point as I see little hope of a permanent living for the Indians, and I am sure that the attendance at such a day school would not justify the large expenditure that would be necessary. The children of that group should go to the Guy School if it is enlarged, and, in the meantime, I do not recommend any great expenditure upon the old day school. The classroom is an old log building which might be temporarily improved by an expenditure of $500.00 for a ceiling of plasterboard, or some such material; replastering of the log walls, and repairs to the floor. Indian Superintendent Jones will submit a requisition in this connection in due course, and I intend to recommend its approval. The teacherage, hardly fit for habitation, has been built in three pieces of very poor log construction, with the result that no expenditure upon that building would make a good building, therefore it cannot be recommended.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir,

I am sorry to have caused you so much inconvenience by my delay in forwarding the invoices of Fairbanks-Morse re Purchase Order 36802. I sincerely thought that I should wait for the completion of the order, which, according to the company, was to be made shortly.

The last mail brought me, at the same time as your letter, another invoice of Fairbanks-Morse, making an additional charge for the control panel which on its way, while I thought that control panel was included in their invoice of March 3rd.

The electric unit reached Atik on March the 25th, i.e., one month after its shipment from the factory. This will explain that the control panel, shipped on March the 21st, was not at Atik yet last Tuesday, and that the confirmation for arrival of same will take some time yet to reach you.

I am glad there is a special mail occasion to-morrow, so these invoices will not be much more delayed. Otherwise they would have left here with the next regular mail, April 25th. After May the 1st however mail service is weekly.

When these two Diesels and the dynamo will be installed, we shall undoubtedly have a very fine installation and all the power we need. We are much indebted to the Department and yourself and thank you most sincerely for thus making our own task easier.

Yours truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,

Dear Father Poirier:

Father Plourde has just telephoned me to the effect that we will have to employ outside labour to install the toilet facilities that we supplied earlier this year. He further advises that you recommend Mr. Watts of The Pas, who is willing to do the work at the rate of $1.80 per hour.

Please let me know by air mail the christian name of Mr. Watts, as we have to obtain the Minister's approval to employ outside labour.

You might also let me know if Mr. Watts will only charge at the rate of $1.80 per hour while he is actually working. Will he provide his own transportation?

As soon as we receive your reply we will give the matter immediate attention, and you will be advised if Mr. Watts' services can be engaged. Do not hire him until you hear from us.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,
PP/ST

Mr. Geo. Watts,
305 Patrick Ave.,
The Pas, Man.

May I say that it takes about a day to cover the distance between The Pas and Sturgeon Landing, due to the bad conditions of the road.

Dear Sir,

Last winter the department sent us 12 new closet bowls to replace the old ones near the children playrooms, and the work is now being done by a plumber from the Pas.

We are just now realizing that the factory, Crane Ltd., has sent no seats for those bowls. I could not say, from the purchase order which I still have on hand and am forwarding to you, whether the seats were included or not in the order.

But there is no doubt that seats are needed, and the children are coming 18 days from now. So with the purchase order, and also one copy of the invoice of Crane which I am forwarding also to you, I am asking you to assist us in procuring these toilet bowl seats in the least possible delay.

So the order would be for 12 on. closet horseshoe seats, without cover.

As to the material, you may decide yourself if they will be straight wood finish, or, as our plumber recommends for public toilets, those Viceroy rubber-wood composition seats which never need anything else than washing and are unbreakable.

Dear Doctor:

Early in August I arranged to visit Guy School, Sturgeon Landing for the postschool inspection on August 29th. I plan on doing this from one week to ten days after the opening of the fall term. A few days before my visit one hundred and forty Patch Tests were sent in with instructions to the Sister nurse in charge that they be placed on the pupils on the 27th of August.

Tom Lamb's Norseman flew Mrs. Dalman, Mrs. Yule and myself to the school on the morning of August 29th. This is the usual assistance I have taken in for the last several years to enable me to do any Tonsil work found necessary amongst the new pupils.

Last year with one hundred and thirty-nine pupils I considered the school well filled, but this year I found one hundred and fifty-six enrolled. This meant that sixteen were not Patch Tested. There were thirty-eight new pupils, the majority of whom I had not examined. It involved a considerable amount of work in making the individual examinations. As many of the new pupils were from British, the tonsil problem from that reserve is at least partially solved. My examination showed that there were about thirty pupils in the whole school requiring their tonsils removed. We started this work on the morning of the 30th. After we had done twenty-five pair we decided to call it a day and left the other five for another time. As there is now a yearly visit by our dentist, no teeth extractions were done.

The Patch Tests were removed and the readings taken on the following day—the 31st. The negative ones (12 boys and 18 girls) were given HCG. The school was given BCG in 1946 which probably accounts for the small number of negative cases. In about two months' time I plan on sending in enough Patch Tests to do the whole school.

The large attendance at once raises the question of overcrowding. I obtained a statement from the Principal giving the size of the various dormitories. I understand that this information is already in your possession. The Manitoba School Act requires 200 cubic feet of air per pupil. If we use this as a yard-stick there is apparently enough air space even for this increased number. The position of the windows permit of adequate ventilation. As there are ninety girls to sixty-five boys the overcrowding is more particularly in the girls' dormitory. However, there are a couple of smaller rooms being used as sleeping quarters for the girls. The staggered hours in the classrooms solve the problem of overcrowding there.

I have recommended to Dr. E.J. Ross, Manitoba Sanitorium Board, and Dr. Ridge that the X-ray Clinic be held at Guy School during the current month. My reasons are as follows,

1. The large number of new pupils.
2. The Saskatchewan pupils. There are fourteen new pupils from Saskatchewan Reserves. These, along with the previously...
enrolled Saskatchewan students, make up approximately half of the enrolment. I understand that no X-ray work was done in Saskatchewan reserves this year.

This matter was discussed personally with both doctors who were in my office the day after my return from Sturgeon Landing. They agreed to carry out my recommendation.

Sister Francois de Jesus, R.N., who has been in charge of this school since September 1941, was forced to return East this summer on account of ill health. She has been replaced by Sister St. Thomas, R.N., who appears to be equally as efficient. While we were very disappointed in losing the services of Sister Francois, we welcome Sister St. Thomas and have no doubt that she will do excellent work.

We found the school being conducted with its usual quiet efficiency. The children are well fed and apparently happy. There appears to be an excellent relationship between the pupils and staff.

The school has one hundred acres of land under cultivation—wheat, oats and barley. If the amount of straw in the fields is any criterion, the yield will be heavy. There was also the usual splendid crop of potatoes, tomatoes, carrots, etc., and raspberries. There was even a crabapple tree loaded with apples. This is in fact a mixed farm with its hens, pigs, cows and horses. However, the major part of the field work is done by tractor.

I might add that we returned to The Pas on Thursday, the 2nd, bringing with us two pupils from the school for hospital attention—Angelique Morin, 15, has developed a T.B. spine, and Joe Bear, 14, was found to have a congenital hernia. Angelique is being sent to Brandon Sanatorium for further treatment (she is a previous San. patient). A Herniotomy was performed on Joe a few days after his arrival at St. Anthony's Hospital.

Yours truly,

(sgd) Robt. F. Yule, M.D.
Medical Superintendent,
The Pas Agency.

Attached also is a blueprint copy of a plan showing the general layout of the school buildings, water and sewer lines and contours over the land adjacent to the buildings.

It will be noted that this school is overcrowded and consideration should be given, in the near future, to the possibility of either enlarging the present building or to the erection of an additional building to provide more housing accommodation. Consideration should also be given to the possibility of erecting a new barn, the present structure being too small and entirely unsuited for the purpose. No estimate of the cost of an addition to the school building or of a new barn can be given as the design in both cases would depend largely upon the funds that could be provided for the purpose.

Mr. Clark has listed, in his report, the items of work that it is recommended should be undertaken during 1950 and his estimate of the cost of this work can be considered to be reasonably close to what the actual cost will be. It is desirable that all the work detailed be proceeded with if the funds are available but early action is very necessary in connection with the replacement of the water supply tank, the materials for which should be delivered to the...
site during the winter months when the hauling can be done over the winter road. The estimate of cost on the replacement of the water supply tank is based upon a tentative design for the replacement of the present tower and tank with one of treated timber. In the event that the present elevated tank was replaced with an underground tank of either concrete or steel, pressure would have to be obtained by the use of a pump and the installation of a pressure tank in the school basement which is already overcrowded.

The reference to the necessity of properly connecting up the wiring of the power plant to the switchboard was referred to Mr. J.P. Ostrander, Regional Supervisor, Indian Affairs Branch on September 22nd and it is possible that this matter has now been attended to.

Dear Sir:

Report: Guy Indian Residential School,
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

According to instructions, proceeded to The Pas
Manitoba. A plane was secured at this point to
make the trip to Sturgeon Landing, where the Guy
Indian Residential School is located.

The inspection included the various buildings
included under the school's jurisdiction, such as
barns, piggery, hen house, machine sheds, warehouses,
garages and out-buildings; also the inspection of
water supply, sewage disposal, lighting and the
inspection of the school building itself.

The population of the school is as follows:
70 boys, 90 girls, 16 sisters, 5 staff, one farm
foreman, one engineer, making a total of 183. The
school is overcrowded; for instance, the older
boys dormitory has been turned into a class room,
and these older boys placed in with the younger ones,
and to facilitate bathing a room in the basement
has been turned into a steam bath, the walls of
which the plaster has broken away exposing the lath.
If this room continues to be used for bathing
would recommend a sheet metal wall be erected to
replace the present one, or plywood.

The principal requests that a Walkin
refrigerator be installed as he finds it extremely
difficult to preserve fresh meats, milk and perish-
able foods. He suggests that this be located
adjoining the pantry directly across the corridor
from the kitchen. To do this the basement wall
would have to be torn out to make room for this installation. He also recommends that the school building be painted on the outside this coming summer. It was painted about 5 years ago, and is showing signs of peeling and deterioration. Altogether, the school building and surrounding buildings are well maintained and with few exceptions in good condition. These exceptions are the elevated water tank, a leak in the roof which has caused the plaster in the dormitories and stair wells to break away from the lath.

The various outbuildings such as machine sheds, garages, warehouses, piggery, henhouse, barn, etc., were in good condition with the exception of the barn. This barn which is 28'6" x 50'0" was erected in 1926, is very poorly placed. The foundation is above the ground level, but the floor is two feet below the ground level, and in freezing weather all the fluid from horses and cattle collects on the floor with no possibility of drainage to the outside of the building, consequently making the floor damp and unsanitary.

The principal of the school, Father Poirier, states that the structure is too small to accommodate the live stock, and recommends that a new structure be erected (at a point suggested on accompanying plan) of suitable dimensions.

The water supply to the school is well planned, and has been well maintained. The only objectionable feature at present is the storage tank. The tank was built in 1926 and at present is in a precarious condition. The bottom is badly warped and the wood is rotten so that the structure is liable to collapse at any time. The tank is constructed on a tower 70 feet high which gives a gravity supply to the school. This should be renewed, or failing that, to construct either a concrete or steel tank with a pressure system similar to other schools. The cost would be approximately the same in either case. If a tower is decided to be erected, would recommend treated timber for the whole structure.

It is recommended that this structure be demolished and a steel or concrete tank installed to take care of the school supply as well as the barn. If a steel tank is decided as suitable, it will have to be shipped during the winter season, as that is the only time heavy materials can be transported to the school from the railway.

The tank can either be buried underground at the rear of the school building or else housed in a small addition to the school building, and steam lines run out from the main building for heating.
Sewage disposal has been well planned. There are two lines, one from the laundry which by-passes the septic tank, and the sanitary line which leaves the main building from the girls' playroom enters the septic tank and goes through to the river. The lines are clear as well as the septic tank, the tank having been pumped out recently.

The heating system has been well maintained and is in good working order. There is only one objection to find, and that is the insulation on both boilers and also the high pressure steam boiler should be renewed as soon as possible. This has broken away in several places.

Power Plant for the school is practically new. This consists of two Diesel Engines and Dynamos. The engine for lighting the buildings has to be started manually as the connection with the switchboard is not hooked up properly. It is recommended that a skilled electrical mechanic be sent in from The Pas and have this attended to as soon as possible, as the school engineer is not familiar with this plant.

The machinery and laundry rooms are badly cramped for space. In the machinery room, the belt from Power Plant to the line shaft is in a dangerous position. It is placed in such a way that any inspection or repair work around the power plant is liable to catch the clothing of the operator.

The following data identifies this engine:

Fairbanks-Morse Engine
48-AG 46, 2 Cyl.
H.P. 16, F106349 Engine No.
R.F.M. 1200
Switch Board connecting the above engine
No. 1090
10 Kw - 120 volts
24V-D.C. Ungrounded control
Battery charging control unit

There are 56 batteries with this unit and they are all in first class condition.

The other engine is controlled manually and is not automatic. It is used for power to water pumps, laundry, bread mixer, etc.

Engine No. F106331
48 A.S. 4 2 Cyl.
H.P. 16, R.F.M. 1200

This unit is in good condition.

A fuel tank should be installed for these units, as all fuel is taken to the engine room in pails, and creates a fire hazard. Would suggest a tank of 400 gallon capacity.
The roof on the north side of the main building is leaking, and in heavy rain and wind the water is forced up under the shingles and in the valleys under the flashing. This condition should be repaired as soon as possible as the plaster in the girls dormitory and also the boys dormitory, on the third floor, is breaking away from the lath which is exposed in several places.

The stair wells walls are in poor shape as the water is getting inside the walls which are bulging out and cracking the plaster on each floor landing. There will be considerable patching to do and would recommend that this work be performed by day labor or cost plus. The work would entail the service of a plasterer and a painter for approximately 90 hours each.

Road from Atik on the Flin-Flon The Pas Railway (C.N.R.) to Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

This road is approximately 25 miles in length and would provide access to the Guy Indian School at all times. This would eliminate the use of airplane travel, and provide transportation of heavy supplies, which are either shipped in winter, or transported from The Pas in Manitoba up the Saskatchewan River to Cumberland House, and thence into Nannu Lake and Sturgeon Landing in the summer.

At present the road is partially cleared and can be used by light trucks in very dry weather. There are a few scratch rock cuttings which will have to be excavated and some drainage work on short muskegs. It is estimated that this road can be put in good shape for two thousand dollars per mile.

The gravel as far as can be ascertained at this time is near the railway line and would necessarily be a long haul, however, it is altogether likely that other deposits will be discovered along the road when the time comes for construction work.

1. The power plant for the school is practically new. This consists of two Diesel Engines and Dynamos. The engine for lighting the buildings has to be started manually, as the connection with the switchboard is not hooked up properly. It is recommended that a skilled electrical mechanic be sent in from The Pas and have this attended to as soon as possible as the school engineer is not familiar with this plant. The necessity of properly connecting up the wiring of the power plant to the switchboard was referred to Mr. J.P. Ostrander.

If you have not found it possible to arrange to send in an electrical mechanic to do the work suggested, it would be appreciated if you would have this man sent at the earliest possible date, as the report states the power plant is practically new and we do not wish it to be damaged by faulty operation.

2. The roof on the north side of the main building is leaking and in heavy rain and wind the water is forced up under the shingles and in the valleys...
under the flashing. This condition should be repaired as soon as possible, as the plaster in the girls' dormitory and also the boys' dormitory on the third floor is breaking away from the lath which is exposed in several places. The walls of the stair wells are in poor shape as the water is getting inside the walls which are bulging out and cracking the plaster on each floor landing. There will be considerable patching to do and would recommend that this work be performed by day labour or cost plus. The work would entail the services of a plasterer and a painter for approximately 90 hours each.

Please communicate with the Principal of the school with a view to determining the best manner of making the above repairs. When we have the information, you can write to us, giving an estimate of the cost.

Bernard F. Neary,
PP/ST
Supt. of Indian Education

Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines & Resources, OTTAWA.

Reverend Father A. Giard, O.M.I., Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School, at Sturgeon Landing, has written Indian Superintendent E.S. Jones regarding the proposal for a new barn at that school.

This was the subject of a report from Mr. W.W. Perrie, Supervising Engineer, Engineering and Construction Division, Department of Mines and Resources, Regina, about three months ago. Nothing was done with regard to making provision in next year's Estimates for this barn, but a new barn is certainly needed.

It is my opinion that about all that could be done this winter with regard to the new barn would be to purchase a quantity of the necessary material from this year's Appropriation (if funds are available), with a view to having the barn erected in 1950. If it is decided to build a new barn at the Guy School, and funds are available in this year's Appropriation to purchase the material, and I am so advised by the Department, I shall ask Indian Superintendent Jones to discuss with Reverend Father Giard the type and size of the barn needed, and, having secured a plan for the purpose, endeavour to purchase most of the material this winter.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Ottawa, March 17, 1936.

Dear Father Doyon:

I have your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing applications for the admission of five children to the Guy Indian Residential School, Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

I am informed that the Department has had correspondence regarding the admission of the three Peterson children, the father of whom is a white man and the mother, Eskimo. As you are, no doubt, aware, the funds provided by Parliament are for the education of Indian children only. The Peterson children take the status of the father and are not wards of the Department. It will therefore not be possible to allow the usual per capita grant in their case.

Relative to the applications for Marie Lina Head and Elise Ballantyne, I have directed that the local Indian Agent, Mr. Pas, report concerning their eligibility for admission to your school. Should his report indicate that these two children are eligible, their admission will be approved.

Yours sincerely,

Reverend N. Doyon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Guy Indian Residential School,
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

Dear Sir:

The Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School has written the Honourable the Superintendent General, regarding the case of two children whom, he states, he has been keeping at the school for some time, and requesting that the Department approve their admission as grant-earning pupils. He forwarded an application for their admission, which I am enclosing, with the request that you will state if these children are wards of this Department. You should ascertain if the parents are Indians and members of a Band or if they are half-breeds, non-treaty or white. Please state, also, if they had been residing on a reserve and living the Indian mode of life thereon. If you consider they are wards of this Department and eligible for admission as grant-earning pupils, I would request that you fill in the number of the ticket under which annuity is paid and sign the applications. Please give as complete information as possible, regarding the status of the two children, and state whether you would recommend that their admission be approved. This should be forwarded at an early date, together with the return of the applications.

Yours truly,

Ottawa, April 14, 1936.

Right Reverend Sir:

Referring to conversation with Your Lordship during your recent visit to the Department, regarding the age limit for the discharge of those boys who are 14 years of age from the residential schools conducted under your auspices, in order that they can be returned to their parents to acquire knowledge of hunting, trapping, etc., I have to say that this meets with the approval of the Department. The Indian Agents at The Pas, Norway House, and Battleford are being informed and requested to advise the Principals of the Guy, Cross Lake and Beauval Indian Residential Schools accordingly.

It is not intended that all the boys, upon attaining 14 years of age, shall be granted discharge, but only those cases which the Principals consider to be in sufficiently good health to accompany their parents on their hunting and trapping trips. It is thought that Indian boys should have acquired sufficient education for their future needs by the time they reach 14 years of age and that it would be to their future advantage to acquire a knowledge of hunting and trapping, on which their future livelihood will, to a great extent, depend.

I would suggest that Your Lordship discuss the matter with the Principals of the above named schools and advise them that careful selection should be made by them of the boys whose discharge they would recommend at 14 years of age.

I have the honour to be,

Right Reverend Sir,

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

Right Rev. M. Lajeunesse, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Keewatin,

Ottawa, April 14, 1936.

Dear Sir:

His Lordship Bishop Lajeunesse, during a recent visit to the Department, discussed the matter of the age limit for the discharge of the boys from the Indian Residential Schools conducted under his auspices. He recommended that those boys who are in good health should be given their discharge when they reach 14 years of age, in order that they can be returned to their parents or guardians, with a view to acquiring a knowledge of hunting and trapping, which will be the main source of their future livelihood.

The Department considers that it would be in the interests of the boys to be granted their discharge at 14 years of age, as they should by that time have acquired an education sufficient to meet their future needs. You may, therefore, inform the Principal of the Guy Indian Residential School that, when he considers that a boy, upon attaining his fourteenth birthday, should receive his discharge, he should make application to the Department, through your office, in the usual manner.

It is not intended that all boys upon reaching 14 years of age are to be discharged, but, as stated, only those who are in sufficiently healthy condition to accompany their parents or guardians in order to acquire a knowledge of hunting, trapping, etc.

I would request that you advise the Principal accordingly.

Yours truly,

J. D. Sutherland,
Acting Supt. of Indian Education.

A. Lovell, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir,

In reply to your letter 132-7-10, dated the 18th instant, I beg to advise that I have investigated the status of these children very carefully.

Marie Lina Head is a halfbreed child whose mother is dead. Her father is living but she has been raised by her grandfather, whose lives in the vicinity of Moose Lake Reserve. She did not live on the Reserve but very close to it. (She is not a treaty Indian or a ward of the Department.)

Elise Ballandyne is a halfbreed child. Her mother is dead and her father is in the sanatorium at Prince Albert. The father brought the child into The Pas when he went into the sanatorium at Prince Albert. She was placed in the Hospital here. The Hospital finally had her transferred to Guy School. (She is not a treaty Indian or a ward of the Department.)

The parents of both these children earned their living and lived in a similar manner to the Indians, that is by hunting and trapping and they also associated with them more or less.

I cannot, and obey the instructions of the Department, recommend them as grant earning pupils. I would say that they are wards of the Provincial Government. These children are destitute and there does not seem to be anyone who will accept responsibility for them.

I will hold the applications here and await your further instructions.

The Secretary,

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 22nd instant, enclosing applications and certificates of health for the admission of Agnes Ballantyne and Elise Charlotte to the Guy Indian Residential School.

In reply I have to inform you that the admission of Agnes Ballantyne is approved.

Regarding Elise Charlotte, it is noted that this girl is not a Treaty Indian. If she is not a half-breed, she would be eligible for admission to the Guy Indian Residential School even though she has not been admitted to Treaty. However, I would request that you advise the Department if she is a full blooded Indian or a half-breed. Has she been residing on an Indian reserve and living the Indian mode of life thereon? When we have this information, consideration will be given as to whether her admission can be approved or not.

Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith voucher No. 291 amounting to $150.00 in favour of the Rev. Father Doyon, Sturgeon Landing Man., for transportation of the children home and returning to the school during holidays.

The Reverend Father submitted an account for $386.60. There was very few details in the statement and a lot of the items were not covered by receipts, and the account itself could not be understood.

As the authority only allows an expense of $150.00, I have had an account made up in this office from the receipts for that amount. I realize that it is desirable to have more details in an expense account of this kind. However if I sent the account back to Sturgeon Landing, it would probably be at least two months before it was returned.

PUBLIC ARCHIVES
ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES
CANADA
Dear Sir,

I am enclosing herewith Application for Admission to Guy Indian Residential School of Laurent Colomb, Matthias Colomb Band.

When this application was first received, I sent it back to the Rev. Father N. Doyon, as I could not find the father's name on our annuity pay-lists. He in turn sent it to the Rev. Father Desormeaux, at Pukitawagan.

I have just received a letter from the Rev. Father Desormeaux and he certifies that this boy is a treaty Indian. His father is known as Arthur Colomb, but in all probability is known by a different name on the treaty books. He does not know his treaty number as he is away at the present time on his trap line and will probably be away all winter.

There are a large number of Colombs in the Matthias Colomb Band and it is impossible for me to know exactly what number this boy is paid under and I will not be able to find out until next year at the annuity payments. As the Rev. Father Desormeaux has certified that this boy is a treaty Indian and as he is already resident in Guy School, I am recommending him for admission.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

18th December 1939.

Sir,

I beg to forward herewith the applications for the admission to the Guy Lake Roman Catholic Indian Residential School, of William Miller, and Jean Miller, both children of Alex Miller No; 453 Cross Lake Band, this agency.

It will be noted that neither of these applications bear the signature of a parent or guardian, as these children are orphans, both parents having died of tuberculosis in 1938 in St Anthony's Hospital at The Pas, and the two children have been at the hospital for a very long time as 'Boarders'.

On receiving a letter from the Indian Agent at the Pas, giving me particulars of the death of the parents, and requesting that someone at the Cross Lake Reserve might adopt them as they were not in fit condition to be admitted to a residential school, I wrote to the Chief at Cross Lake and asked him to make enquiries, but there were apparently no relatives there, and no one wanted to adopt them on account of their condition of health. I tried again at treaty time this past summer, to have some Indian at Cross Lake take charge of these children, but without success.

As stated on the application form, by the examining physician, Dr Falconer, the children have been under supervision at St Anthony's hospital for the past six months, and they can now be sent safely to a residential school.

I may say that I never saw either of the parents, as they never lived on the Cross Lake since I came to Norway House, but at Pikwitonei, Man; and their annuities were always sent to them by mail until this year.

Will you kindly advise me of the decision of the Department regarding the above applications.

Your obedient Servant

P.G. LaZenby.

Reverend Sir:

A review of the December quarter return of the Guy Indian Residential School shows that Henrietta Morin, No. 0136, is over the age of 16.

No application for retaining this child in your school has been received and in this connection I wish to direct your attention to circular letter of July 21, 1939, a copy of which is enclosed.

As pointed out in the circular letter the Department realizes that frequently there are reasons for keeping certain children after they reach the age of 16 but at the same time the consent of the Superintendent General (Minister) must be obtained.

I may add that in the past the Department has been favourably disposed to allowing certain pupils, especially girls, to remain in residential schools after they reach the age of 16 if good reasons for such action are given by the Principal and approved by the Indian Agent. However, in view of the fact that the number of children of school age is apparently increasing and the further consideration that due to the conditions now confronting us there is no immediate prospect of our securing funds to provide increased pupilage at Indian residential schools, it is considered that in future it will be necessary to adhere more strictly to the provision of the Indian Act requiring discharge of pupils at 16 years of age.

I feel you will agree with me that it is not fair to deprive children of education simply because the accommodation that might be available for them in

Rev. N. Doyon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Guy Indian Residential School,
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.
a residential school is being used by those who have had the advantage of residential school training for some years and who have reached the age of 16 years.

Until further advised you should make arrangements for the discharge of pupils when they reach the age of 16 unless there are some very exceptional circumstances and in this event full particulars should be given to the Department and our permission obtained before such pupils reach the age of 16.

With the above in mind I desire to hear from you at the earliest possible date stating the date on which the pupil mentioned in the first part of this letter can be discharged from your school.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES

CANADA
Dear Sir,

The Rev. Father Doyen, Principal of Guy Indian Residential School, is in the habit of taking destitute half-breed children into the School as resident pupils.

These children are not examined by Dr. Falconer and as far as I know are not examined by any doctor; consequently there is a grave possibility of these children taking disease into the School. There were three children admitted to the school last week. These children came from a district where there was diptheria. It so happened that the Provincial Medical Health Officer heard about it and mentioned it to Dr. Falconer and the children were put into Hospital for a few days for observation. While there they developed chicken pox.

It would seem to me that destitute half-breed children are a Provincial responsibility. When they are admitted to Guy School, even if they are not grant earning pupils, they become, to a certain extent, a responsibility of the Department as far as medical attendance and education is concerned.

If the Principal is to be allowed the unrestricted privilege of admitting half-breed children, one can easily see, that at times, it would lead to overcrowding.

I would therefore like the Department to give me a ruling on this matter. Is the Principal entitled to admit children without reference to the Department. I refer of course to non-grant earning pupils.

Your obedient servant,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Ottawa,
April 18, 1940.

Dear Sir:

I am in receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with reference to admitting destitute halfbreed children to the Guy Indian Residential School.

The Guy Indian Residential School was erected and is maintained for Treaty Indian children. Consequently halfbreed children should not be admitted even though the Department is not requested to allow any grant for their maintenance.

The Department realizes that it is sometimes necessary to allow children to enter the Guy School before official approval has been received from us but only Treaty Indian children should be accepted in this manner. Any doubtful case should not be admitted but full particulars should be forwarded to this office and our decision given before a child is allowed to enter the school.

However, as stated above, destitute halfbreed children whose maintenance is a Provincial responsibility must not be taken into the Guy Indian Residential School. If there are any such children in this school at the present time you should advise the Principal that the Department desires them discharged immediately and you should advise this office when such action has been taken.

Yours truly,

Mr. S. Lovell,
Indian Agent,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir:

You should so inform the Principal and co-operate with him in arranging to have the Indian parents bring their children to and from the school this year.

I should appreciate receiving a reply to official letter of the 18th ultimo with reference to the taking of destitute halfbreed children into the Guy School.

Dear Sir:

I have your recent letter enclosing account showing expenditure made by the Principal of the Guy Residential School in connection with the transportation of children to and from the school during the past summer. The Department is surprised that the Principal encouraged such extremely heavy expenditure. If it was not possible to transport the children more economically than in the manner which he adopted it is felt that the children should have remained at the school instead of being sent home for holidays.

Last year we allowed an amount of $75.00 for travelling expenses of children going on holidays from this school. It is very difficult for us to increase this amount to any large extent. However, it has been decided to allow $100.00 this year. You may, therefore, submit a voucher in his favour for $100.00. You should attach to it the accounts from the Arrow Airways Limited which I am returning to you.

Dear Bishop Lajeunesse:

We are in receipt of a request for a grant toward the transportation of children going on holidays from the Guy Residential School during the summer of 1941. Last year we allowed $75.00 for this service and it is extremely difficult for us to increase this amount to any large extent. However, it has been decided to provide $100.00.

The Principal has submitted accounts showing that he expended a total of $1225.40 for return transportation of children to their homes for holidays. All this amount was expended for aeroplane travel.

In view of conditions existing at the present time I am surprised that the Principal of any residential school would incur such an extremely heavy expenditure for the purpose mentioned. Even though the money is being paid from school funds the Department is vitally interested because if this expenditure had not been incurred for that purpose the money would have been available for other necessities at the school.

It is felt that if the children could not be sent home by some more economical means of transportation they should have been kept at the school during the holidays. I should appreciate it if you would give this matter your very careful

Rt. Rev. M. Lajeunesse, O.M.I.,
Bishop of Keewatin,
The Pas, Man.
consideration. You are aware of the difficulty we have in obtaining funds for our residential schools and I think you will agree with me that there should be no repetition of such heavy expenditure next year.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Department of Mines and Natural Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Dear Sir:

Re: Guy Residential School and Air transportation costs.

This is to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 31st of October last in which you express surprise at such an expenditure for aeroplane travel and in which you advise the allowance of $100.00 this year to cover the costs.

This problem is extremely difficult to solve and it is not with very much enthusiasm that we resort to airway transportation for the children. We tried this year to have the Pelican Narrows Indians bring their children by canoe and while they promised to do so, nothing in fact resulted. We were obliged to round them up again by plane.

Your suggestion to keep the children at school during the summer months would most likely bring about a more complex situation, a fast declining school enrollment.

However, we appreciate your remarks and we will give the matter further consideration with the hopes of finding some means for the better.

Sincerely,

[Vicar Apostolique du Keewatin]

Dear Sir -

Yesterday I had a letter from our Indian Agent stating that Josephine Merasty No 011 was shown on the Dec. return but does not appear on March quarterly return. I beg to say that this is a mistake of my secretary, for the said girl is certainly in the school. Would you please notify your secretary about this matter?

If the quarterly grant has been paid out entirely, I would suggest that the $43.75 due for the above girl will be placed with the $500.00 we are expecting from your Dept. for the road I really need so badly.

You can be sure that if the money is granted for the road, I will do my very best to have the work done properly without any remuneration whatever for my trouble.

We received lately a special grant for the school that was very welcome and for which we are very thankfull to you and your Dept. I understand the situation, the difficulties of the present time, but the necessities created by the local circumstances pressed me to ask.

I have here this morning the agent of the Singer Sewing Machine Co., for inspection of our machines in the school. You will receive his report and see that the request I have made for new machines was not without any reasons.

I received from your Dept. all the paint that has been granted for the outside painting of the school. The quantity will certainly not be sufficient, but all of it will be carefully spread over during the summer. As I want to finish the painting of the inside of the school, I already ordered 15 galls of white paint and 10 galls of cement paint for the playrooms and kitchen and dining-rooms. All this and the work will be paid by the school, for I am always anxious to keep on with the success of this school in every point of view.

Hope this letter will find your kind approbation.

April 23, 1942.

Reverend Sir:

I have carefully considered the contents of your letter of April 11. I note that you are discharging all pupils at 15 years of age. I would like to know if there is any special reason for this action. At other residential schools they have found that it is desirable to keep the girls at least until 16 years of age.

The funds at our disposal will not permit our making any definite promise regarding assistance to ex-pupils. As a matter of fact, I doubt if distribution of assistance is the best manner in which to assist ex-pupils. The majority of these have been in residential schools for many years at Government expense and have received training and every possible physical care and attention. At some period of their lives they must expect to do something for themselves. It is, therefore, felt that the exercise of influence toward this end on the part of Indian Agents and Missionaries would probably be the best assistance that we could give them. The whole matter is a very broad one and will require a great deal of consideration before any definite policy can be reached. In the meantime, however, we hope that our Principals of residential schools will impress on those graduating that the Department expects them to make a real effort to put in use the training that they have received at school. If this is done the Department will be more inclined to grant them some assistance later.

Yours truly,

Rev. N. Doyon, O.M.I.,
Principal,
Guy Indian Residential School
Sturgeon Landing, Sask.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

On September last, I asked the discharge of Emile Merasty who was not yet back in school and was also unexpected. The discharge was accepted by the Dept. Fortunately that boy came back to school at the beginning of October. I wonder if the Dept. will accept him, and on the same number 154 he had last year. If not I will ask the Dept. to deduct the 67 days the lad has been in school from the aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter.

At this time of the year I cannot send away that pupil if only by plain, and the cost is too high; rather keep him in school for his own welfare.

With thanks,

Yours truly,

Rev. H. Dyson, P.D.S.

Dear Sir,

I am sending herewith the quarterly return to the end of June. Here are some explanations about a few particulars.

In yours of April 10th, you had asked that the children so far marked as "not back to school" should be discharged if they were unlikely to return. By enquiring from the teachers and from the other children, it appears that all or mostly all of those "not back to school" will likely be back here in September. Therefore I have left their names once more on the report, but if they fail to return by next term, then I will put them on the list of children to be discharged.

Re pupil 0207, Gertrude Merasty, the number of days in residence exceeds the number of days in quarter, because the days of her presence during the precedent term have been added to those of this term, because her name was not on the last report, since she was not yet officially admitted. About this pupil, may I ask you that one copy of her "Application for admission" and "Physical examination" be sent back to school to file with the others for reference.

Re pupil 0206, Marie Claire Bighetty, something very extraordinary has occurred. That child has been in school and attending class for 2 full years and you may verify that it is now the first time that her name figures in the quarterly return. Apparently the principal must have forgotten to give that name to the teacher along with the other names of the children officially admitted as per your list in a letter dated October 4, 1941. So the teacher must have thought this pupil not yet officially admitted and had kept on omitting that name in the class attendance record, which is used to make up the quarterly return. I have discovered this serious omission in making out this report and I call your attention to the fact that the grant for this child has not yet been paid since two years. The total number days of her attendance during this whole period is 684. Should this number be put on this term instead of 91, thus increasing by 593 the Total No of days pupil residence during Quarter and making it 11,151? The average attendance of pupils during quarter would thus become 121.4. If this way of doing is right, may I ask you to change yourself the figures on the report, or if you will advise on another procedure to be taken, I will gladly hear about it.

Truly yours,
