Dear Sir,

I beg leave to present to you and the Indian Department a demand of admission to school which has to do with special conditions.

Charles Charlette, a resident of Sturgeon Landing, originally a Cold Lake Indian, but non-treaty, has been with the permission of the Department admitted in our Residential Schools, seven years at Duck Lake and three years here at Sturgeon Landing. His wife died two weeks ago, leaving him four children she had from her first husband, Thomas Morin of South End (or Pelican), who was treaty-Indian, and two young ones who are Charles' own children.

Three of the Morin already have belonged to the school for years and still do, they being "Treaty" by both of their parents, and now at Charles Charlette's request I present to you his demand to have at least the older of his children, a girl of nearly four years called Nancy, also admitted to the school with her half-brothers and half-sister.

The mother of Nancy Charlette was a Treaty Indian, her father is an ex-pupil of the school and his misfortune makes him incapable of keeping care of her. I strongly hope that the Department will deem those reasons sufficient to approve the admission to Guy school of the said child, under age but with nobody else to take care of her.

As to the baby, seven months old, his father is looking for someone to adopt and raise him, not wanting to ask that much from the Department and the school staff.

I want to express here my deep regret of having been unable so far to call on you when in The Pas, sometimes on account of your absence, and sometimes because I am there only at night. I hope that before long I shall have the occasion and pleasure to meet you.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]
Principal.

"Search was underway yesterday by Royal Canadian Mounted Police for three boys who have been missing from the Sturgeon Landing Indian school, near here, since May 18. The boys are Joseph Colomb, 16, and Jeremie Colomb, 15, both of Pukatawagan, Man., and Frank Morin, of Pelican Narrows, Man."

At about 9.30 Pm Cst., Rathbone I/c The Pas Detachment received a telephone call from Father E. Ringuet to the effect that he had received information by letter delivered to him by Indian Messenger Joseph Morin that three boys had escaped from the Indian School at that point (Sturgeon Landing Mission School). The letter when translated from French to English went something as what follows:

Three boys have escaped the Sturgeon Landing Indian School yesterday the 18th at 4:30 P.M.

We don't know what direction they have taken. It is quite possible they went to Atik if they have succeeded to cross the river not very far from the school; that can be done.

Boys Names:
Joseph Colomb 16 years old from Pakitawagan
Jeremie Colomb 15 " " " from Southend or Pelican Narrows.
Frank Morin 15 " " " from Southend or Pelican Narrows.

The two Colomb are quite familiar with Cold Lake. They are wearing their weekly suits (overalls black sweater with colored stripes, and may be a blue jacket) or wind-breaker.

As far as the Principal knows the boys have just a very little quantity of food with them. Joseph Colomb is just as tall as an ordinary man; the others have the average height of boys of their age.

The Principal of the School says no other directions could have been taken than the one to Atik. If they have taken another direction, Father's fear is that the boys most likely counted on more strength than they possess to reach any other point.

E. Ringuet, OMI

On the morning of the 20th accompanied by Joseph Morin, Messenger, we left The Pas at 4.30 Am by Police Car and proceeded to Atik. I left at this hour to be ahead of the train leaving The Pas at 7.20 Am and thus cut off these boys should they attempt to catch the train at Atik they did not board this train so I proceeded to Cranberry Portage making enquiries enroute, anticipating that I would have to go inland I returned to Mile 39 where I met Father L. Peirier, Priest, in charge of Sturgeon Landing Mission. Father Peirier had a canoe and motor and I accompanied him in a search of the north end of Goose Lake to Rat Creek, there were no signs to indicate that the three runaway boys were on this lake, it was then arranged that I would return and make inquiries elsewhere. Father Peirier covered the remaining portion of Goose Lake on his return to the mission, and I would report results on my return.
Continued from page one. Leaving P. Peirier at Mile 99 I continued with enquiries at Simonhouse, Atik, and Wanless and questioned the camp operators and section men without success. I had been in touch with Capt. Rathbone earlier in the day and it was arranged that I would return to The Pas arriving in late PM at Atik, Man. I was requested by Fred Petryk, the contractor to bring Edward Cook to The Pas for medical treatment. He was suffering from crushed fingers. This is a subject of a separate report.

On the evening of the 22nd, I met Father Peirier on his arrival at The Pas from Sturgeon Landing Mission when he advised that the three boys had returned voluntarily to the mission. It appears that these three boys stole a canoe at near Sturgeon Landing and travelled as far as an island located about the center of Goose Lake, where they camped until May 20th, and were forced to return to the mission due to lack of food and clothing and necessary means to defend themselves against wolves which are thick in that area. They apparently suffered no ill affects from their experiences and were happy to return to the mission.

Regarding the canoe stolen by these boys the same was the property of Father Peirier and he has no desire to press a charge of Theft of Canoe.

CONCLUDED

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division,
Indian Affairs, Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

The article you have seen in the Winnipeg Free Press about three boys missing from Sturgeon Landing school was not without reason, but I am afraid it has caused you undue apprehension. Here is what happened.

In the afternoon of May 18, shortly before supper time, three boys took to the bush, running away from school. The boys were Joseph Colomb, 16 years old, from Pakitawagan; Jeremie Colomb, 15, from the same place, and Frank Morin, 14, from South End Reindeer Lake. I was notified about their absence at 6.30 p.m.

I was sure that those boys were not lost accidentally, but that they had fled on purpose. For bad conduct they had been excluded from a reward given that same afternoon to many other children, but they were the only three big boys not to be there; they knew it in advance and they had planned their evasion for that day.

Where did they want to go? Home, evidently, but their homes were far away; so they would likely go to the nearest Indian settlements, and the fastest way to get there, if not the only one, was the railroad, 23 miles away from the school.

I thought they might change their minds the same evening or during the night and I did not organize any pursuit right away, I just had all the buildings watched very closely all night for fear of fire.

On the morning of May 19, as they were not back, I sent a messenger to The Pas to notify the Agent or the Mounted Police; the Agent was not home, but the Police was asked to keep an eye on Cold Lake near Sherridon, and Beaver Lake, near Flin Flon where they would likely go if they had money to get on the train.

In the meanwhile I went myself at the end of an 8 mile road leading to Goose Lake, where I had left a canoe the week before and they might have used to go to the railroad if they would rather paddle than walk. The canoe was gone!... It was before noon when I found that out, so I went right back with the truck to get another canoe and a motor and I went as fast as I could right to the rail, Mile 39 of the Flin Flon Railway; my canoe was not there yet, so I was...
ahead of them and had cut their shortest way of escape by water. They were probably somewhere on the lake but it was too late that evening to start and search around the shore; so I camped there and in the early morning I saw the gas-car of R.C.M.P. coming from The Pas; they had made sure already that the boys had not taken the train yet and so they could not be farther than Cranberry Portage; so I went as far as there with the special constable, we searched for a while on the lake and then I went back toward home, while the Police was going back to The Pas where I promised to go on Monday 22, to tell them if I had found the children or not.

At 7 p.m. of May the 20th, when I got back to the place where my canoe had been, and from where it had been taken, the canoe was back in its place, and on the wheel of the truck I had left there was a note from the Boys: "We are going back home, we are sorry for what we have done."

When I got to the school at 9 p.m., they had been there 3 hours ahead of me.

After two nights in the bush, with no blankets and but very little grub, and still a long way to go, and with pursuers already ahead of them, and wolves and bears to scare them, they had lost their enthusiasm for anything further.

They admitted afterwards that their plan was to reach the railroad, but since they had no money they had planned to walk the railroad up to Flin Flon, a walk of over 50 miles.

This school is so far from all communications and from Indian Reserves that it is fairly impossible for a child to run away with any chance of making it home; that is why an incident like this one is absolutely exceptional in the history of the school. And the failure of these boys to make it is likely to discourage any other attempt for a long time.

Joe Colomb is being discharged because he is of age; Jeremie Colomb, who was the leader of the trio, will not be allowed to come back; he is old enough too and besides that his conduct makes him absolutely undesirable; as to Frank Morin, the youngest of the three, we are ready to take him again next year.

I am sorry that the matter came up to the Press because it may have caused wrong impressions and regrettable reactions against the school, where otherwise I am certain that practically all the children enjoy to be.

As for you, though, I am glad that you knew it, for it shows me what interest you take in whatever concerns the schools.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Principal.

Ottawa, January 24, 1945.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Manitoba.

The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

In reply to your letter 132-7-10, dated the 24th instant, I beg to advise that the children who are absent from G y School are truants.

They would not return when the Principal went for them after the holidays, though a plane was chartered to bring them back. Most of them belong to the Nelson House Band and reside at South Indian Lake.

I told the Chief of the Nelson House Band about this matter and asked him to assist us to get the children back, but I find nothing was done. It would be difficult to bring these children back other than by plane. The School authorities are not willing to charter a plane again to go to South Indian Lake to try and get the children to return, as it is too expensive. I could, if the Department would authorize it, charter a plane and take a R.C.M.P. constable in and bring out the children. This is the only way we would be able to get them back to School.

S. Lovell,
Indian Agent.
The Secretary, Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I beg to advise that the Right Rev. M. Lejeuness, Bishop of the R.C. Diocese of Keewatin, came to the Office a few days ago and requested me to write to the Department and ask permission to admit to Guy School the undermentioned children of William Chartier of Gillam, Man. This man is in the Sanatorium suffering from T.B. There is very little chance of him being able to support his children in future and they are now destitute. The Bishop tells me there is no other School these children can be admitted to. He is not asking that these children be admitted as grant earning pupils, only that they be allowed to remain in the School. Their maintenance will be provided for by the Church.

Kindly let me know your decision regarding the Bishop's request as soon as possible.

S. Lovell,

Ottawa, March 26, 1945.

Mr. S. Lovell, Indian Agent, The Pas, Man.

I have your letter of the 9th instant, with reference to the request of the Right Reverend M. Lajeunesse, Bishop of Keewatin, to allow the children of William Chartier to be placed in the Guy Indian Residential School as non-grant-earning pupils.

I presume from your letter that Mr. Chartier is not an Indian, and consequently his children would not be eligible for admission to an Indian residential school as grant-earning pupils. However, regarding the request to have them admitted as non-grant-earning pupils, similar applications have been received in the past and have always been refused. Many complications would result from having white children admitted to an Indian residential school. I feel it is unnecessary for me to outline what these complications would be, as I am certain they will readily suggest themselves to you. Taking everything into consideration, the Department regrets that we cannot see our way clear to grant Bishop Lajeunesse's request.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Extract From Inspector Hamilton's Report dated 6th August, 1945.

The Chief and Councillors spoke well and expressed appreciation for what the Government had done to assist them. They appeared very grateful about the Family Allowance. All complained regarding the Guy School at Sturgeon Landing. They wanted more education in the classroom and they wanted the children to receive a better training in cooking, sewing and in plain carpentering. They laughed at the idea of doing fretwork and said the boys should know how to make handles for tools and cut rafters and boards. They pointed out this was the kind of work they would be required to do and so they should have training along this line.

There is no day school; about 20 children go to the Guy School. There are perhaps 100 others who receive no education. A much larger number should be sent to the Guy School - certainly there should be no trouble in securing their full quota. Last year there was measles and whooping cough among the Indians when the children were supposed to go to School and many did not return. They were told very emphatically that all children enrolled must return and that other children must be sent so that the school is filled to capacity.

"New Pupils - There are 30 new pupils in the school and only two or three had been examined on the Reserves. As it turned out the Clinic did not get in and three of these cases are now at Clearwater Lake Sanitorium. I expect to have at least three more before spring. RE: Air Travel Expenses Summer 1945, for the Guy Indian Residential School.

Attention: Mr. Phelan.

My dear Mr. Phelan:

Enclosed please find recruiting expenses for the year 1945, of the Guy Indian Residential School. Last year you paid part of these expenses and I hope that you will be able to do the same again.

I well remember your remarks about the very unusual conditions prevailing at this school and the hope that you expressed that during the coming years, a reversion to the old method of travelling might be undertaken.

The Principal informs me in the letter covering this matter that water conditions are so bad that it is impossible for the parents of these Indian children to undertake to bring them to school by the old canoe method. The number of portages is so great that the expenses would be almost as high as air travel. Furthermore, the Principal advises me that as soon as water conditions favour a change to the old methods that he will certainly have recourse to them in his recruiting.

Under these circumstances I hope that you will do your best to pay as large a proportion as you can of the enclosed accounts.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

CANADA
Report concerning AIR TRAVEL EXPENSES for children
of the Guy Indian Residential School to and from their homes.

In 1941, when for the first time accounts were submitted to the Indian Affairs Branch for aeroplane transportation of children to and from school for their holidays, it aroused much surprise at Ottawa, and the hope was expressed by them that such expenditures would not have to be repeated. To the contrary, and notwithstanding the desire of the school authorities to avoid expenses that the Department could not approve and the payment of which they did not share, the air travel expenses for children have been steadily increasing from year to year, and while the accounts of 1941 showed the amount of $1225.00, the accounts of 1946 are showing the staggering figure of $3225.00. The Indian Affairs Branch will evidently and rightly look for an explanation; I shall try to give it by presenting the history of children transportation to this school, and comparing the present system of transportation with the other alternatives.

* * * * *

-Location of the school,
-Canoe travelling,
-Such travelling was made for other reasons than children:

Sturgeon Landing, Sask., was proposed as a good location for an Indian Residential School in the 1920s; it was certainly at the time a very reasonable choice. Sturgeon Landing was not indeed close to any of the Reserves it was intended to serve, but it was situated on the main road leading to all those reserves; Sturgeon Landing was truly then the Gateway of the North.

From Pelican Narrows, South Reindeer Lake, Pakitawagan, canoes came every summer to get the supplies of the fur companies; those canoe trips were not then any shorter nor easier than they are now. From 100 to 400 miles one way, up and down rivers strewn with rapids, over long or steep or swampy portages numbering as many as forty on one trip, across lakes where wind and furious waves would hold them often for days on the shore, stormed by mosquitoes or drenched by heavy rains with only a light tent for protection, sweating by day and freezing by night, the Indian travellers bravely carried on their backs or took to the northern posts the supplies of the Hudson's Bay Company or other companies, on which depended their living for the following winter.

Those freighters worked thus all summer and thought nothing of it because it was their livelihood: without those goods they would have nothing from the stores in the winter, and besides, they were paid for this canoe freighting. Therefore it was not asking too much of the Indians to add their children to the load in June and to bring them in their empty canoes in August. As long as they were given food supplies for the kids, they were just glad because their travelling expenses and their time were paid for from other sources anyhow.

Very often indeed did the children arrive at school sick, after such trips where so much depends on the weather. When an Indian is travelling with his family, wife and children, he is not as a rule in a hurry and whenever the weather threatens, they pitch the tent and make everything comfortable as they can for the children, ready to wait until good conditions prevail; when men are travelling for freight, it is different; they do not like to stop unless it is really tough, because they are not usually supplied with food for any more than the average time required for this trip, and if they stop too long they will starve, and this happened more than once.
So hardship often resulting in sickness was encountered in those trips, and a great number of sick and dead during the first ten years of the school might well be traced back to those hardships of travel.

Such were in 1926 the transport "facilities" - if it is not mockery to call them so - for the children of the Guy School of Sturgeon Landing. In the circumstances they were indeed facilities, as experience was to prove.

-Change of conditions with building of railway:

At the same time the school was being built in 1925-26, a much bigger enterprise was heading North, and that was to spell the end of Sturgeon Landing as the Gateway of the North. Flin Flon was developing and a railway was being built from The Pas to the new mining camp, soon to be a town; it was passing twenty three miles east of the school and the only access to it in summer was (and pretty well is yet) a difficult canoe route of thirty miles. If the actual developments of this region could have been foreseen then, it is doubtful whether Guy School would have been erected where it stands now.

The new railway opened up Flin Flon and Sherridon, bringing to an end the water transportation between The Pas and Sturgeon Landing, and between this place and the northern posts. The hitherto "facilities" of transportation described above vanished with the settlement and very few families of Indians and Halfbreeds were all that was left in Sturgeon Landing besides the school.

The water route of long ago always remained opened from Sturgeon Landing north, but who was to use it when there was no more freight to get and no more retribution for the hardwork of the trip? And soon there was to be no summer freight at all for the Indians, as the tractors from the mining centres were to reach all the Indian settlements of the region on winter roads.

From Pelican Narrows, South End and North Reindeer Lake (Brochet) some Indians still volunteered to come as far as Sturgeon Landing for their children, but already the school had to pay more in food and other help to make sure that the Indians would keep coming. While there was no more freight from Sturgeon Landing, there was also work now in the North for the Indians who cared to work and the men would not undertake weeks of canoe travel without pay just for the sake of taking their children to school.

From Pakitawagan the railroad provided some help to cover a great part of the distance. But Sturgeon Landing is 30 miles by water from the railroad and Pakitawagan from Sherridon is a two day canoe trip when conditions are at their very best: the wind on Cold Lake has often stopped the canoes for days at a time, and the same thing happened between the railroad and Sturgeon Landing on Goose Lake. So it meant organizing a flotilla of canoes from the school to the railroad and make sure that another flotilla would be at the other end of the rail to receive them, while there was no accommodation in Cold Lake for the children. It was often worse when the children were coming back; there had to be somebody from the school waiting for the children in Cold Lake (Sherridon) while a group of men and canoes had to wait at Goose Lake for an indefinite number of days. Everything taken into account, there was hardly anything to gain with the railroad.

So from all sides the expenses, time and trouble gone into for the transportation of the children, the dissatisfaction of the Indians and the dangers of all kinds for the pupils, the consequently increasing difficulties of recruiting, everything definitely called for a change and the plane was all indicated.
First plane trips,
Canoe vs plane:

The first plane trips for children were made in June 1940. In August many children came back by air too. This first trial proved satisfactory and in 1941 a few more trips were made, the accounts of which aroused the Department at the time.

An account in the thousand dollars for transportation of children had likely not been seen yet at the Indian Affairs, except maybe in the form of payment for the purchase of busses or trucks used for gathering up children or taking them home in some other schools.

This expense was startling at first sight, but further exploration of the question would show that the expense was not at all a new item nor a new figure in the list of disbursements.

"Transportation", be it air transportation or other kind, had always been a burden to the school, especially since the canoe freighting had stopped; the $5 per 100 dollars contributed annually by the Branch specifically for the transportation of children was never more than a token retribution compared to the real expenses incurred therein, in the form of wages, gasoline, motors and canoes, food and clothing, a decreasing enrolment and the plain loss of children through sickness, some of those and other items not to be counted in dollars and cents.

Right now it is generally admitted in this part of the country that to travel far the plane is still the cheapest way, -and the Indians themselves widely use it.

There are not here, like in other northern regions great water routes to afford easy and cheap communications from one place to the other. To make sure of that, I did not only look at the maps of the country, but since I have been appointed principal of this school, I have been out two summers, more than a month altogether, to see by canoe and all that was necessary, our children come from, and the description I have attempted above of the country and of canoe travelling is not only hearsay: it is sheer experience. I could have made the same trips by plane with less expense and in a much easier way, but then I would not have felt confident enough to present this plea in favor of plane transportation for our children.

Increasing accounts and why:

The aeroplane accounts have been going up though since the start, and this is due to several causes:
1/ the rates of the flying companies have been raised;
2/ their conditions have become onerous, v.g., as not to take so many children as before in one aircraft,-or refusing to make charter trips between regular schedule stops;
3/ the proportion of children from places cared for by air has increased, so as to be the near totality now:105 this last August; so that higher fares and more children from far are the only explanation of the later accounts.

Contributions of the Branch:

The contribution of the Indian Affairs Branch to the transportation of children since the plane is used has been increasing too, as these figures show:

| Year | Amount |
|------|--------|
| 1941 & 1942 | $100.00 |
| 1943 | $150.00 |
| 1944 | $450.00 |
| 1945 | $550.00 |

The better interests of the school and of the Indians were evidently seen and I again take the opportunity to thank very sincerely the officers of the Branch for their more generous help in these later years.
Great sacrifices though have still to be made by the school or the church authorities who pay the major part of the children transportation. It is that much money that can not be spent otherwise for the benefit of the children, but with a school only half full the school finances would be still in a worse position.

Conclusion and request:

All governments insist so much nowadays on education that the actual opportunities of Guy School ought not to be left unemployed for lack of adequate means of transportation. The reason for plane transportation I hope I have made clear enough, and if Guy School is to remain opened to Indian children I beseech the authorities of the Indian Affairs Branch not to oppose this way of doing, which was forced upon us by circumstances herein explained.

If this report may cause the Indian Affairs Branch officials to admit and even to approve it is hoped, the actual method of transportation of children to Guy School, may they have the Branch assume a greater part if not all of the payment of the said transportation. The consequences of such a move, may they rest assured, would be all to the benefit of the children themselves whose welfare they so earnestly desire.

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

re Cecilia Jebb and Michael Jebb,
Application for admission.

You will find herewith the Application for Admission of Cecilia and Michael Jebb, sister and brother of Therese Jebb, already in this school, #0274, 13 yrs old.

The mother of these children, herself a former pupil of this school, has asked us to take care of her children, while she has been called for a stay in the Sanatorium. Cecilia is old enough to go to class and will likely stay with us even after her mother's recovery.

Michael being too young will be returned to his mother if and when she goes back home. Though Michael's form is not completed on the Physical Examination side, he has been taken in the school only with the consent of our Medical Superintendent, Dr. R.F. Yule.

Doctor Yule however has not deemed necessary to fill in the form since he thinks that the little boy's stay will only be temporary.

Since the school is not quite full to capacity, I nevertheless ask the Indian Affairs Branch to officially admit Michael Jebb, so that he may be included in the Quarterly Return for the per capita allowance.

If it is your advice, I shall have the form normally completed at the next visit of the Doctor.

Yours truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Principal.

attention: Mr. Philip Phelan.

Dear Sir,

I am submitting herewith to your examination the two accounts we had to pay this summer in order to send the children home for their holidays and get them back here.

Last year I sent with the accounts a detailed explanation of the conditions which make necessary for us these abnormally big transportation expenses. On the total amount then of $3,225.00 the Indian Affairs Branch has refunded to us the sum of $1,500.00, for which I was most grateful.

The conditions which asked for these expenses have not changed, and therefore I submit these new accounts, which have already been paid by the R.C. Episcopla Corporation at The Pas, with the hope that a similar help may be extended to us once more. And why not express openly my confidence that eventually, through your sympathetic understanding of our difficulties, the Department will himself absorb more and more the payment of this extraordinary expenditure.

You will note that we have been able to carry a few passengers other than school children on these chartered trips and this has helped us to a certain amount.

in Aug. 1,660.00
3,235.00

I remain,

I regret that the loss of the first accounts may be giving you more work, but I hope you will be able yet to help us.

Thanking you in advance,

I remain yours truly,

Guy Indian Residential School Quarterly Report for quarter ending September 30th enclosed. Please note, that the 35 pupils marked truant, are listed as being in residential quarters for 46 days. I might add that these children did not return to school this term, and are on their Reserves.

OTTAWA November 13th, 1948.

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: Duration of School Year at the A.M.
Guy Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Reverend Father L. Poirier, O.M.I., Principal of the above school, says in a letter received today that the children of this school left for their homes by plane, on the 14-15-16- of June. The children returned on the 16th and 17th of August, as the 15th fell on a Sunday.

Strictly speaking, it may be said that the children left on the 16th of June and returned on the 16th of August which would constitute the two months of vacation which they are allowed on the school reports. The leaving date was put down as June the 15th and the returning date was the 15th of August.

Reverend Father Poirier says that the Department wrote to him last year to find out why summer vacations were allowed on the dates mentioned above and adds that his answer to your letter must have been found satisfactory as neither your agent or your office wrote again about the subject.

Hoping that the above explanation will be found satisfactory,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
November 23, 1948.

Mr. E. Law,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
The Pas, Manitoba.

We have received your letter of October 15th with reference to the September quarter return of the Guy Residential School.

Please note that the return requires the principal to show the number of days in the quarter. That means that on the March quarter return he shows 90 days, on the June quarter 91 days, on the September quarter 92 days and on the December quarter 92 days.

The return as prepared by the principal was correct. Attached is a copy of a circular letter regarding the preparation of the quarterly return and I would also direct your attention to the instructions contained on the quarterly return form.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division.

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan.

Dear Sir,

Once more I am coming to you with quite a big bill of expense for the transportation of our children last summer. Though the number of children has increased at the school re-opening, I have been able to manage so that the air travel accounts did not increase in proportion.

Air travel is becoming ever more common in this part of the country, so much that the Indians themselves coming out to the railroad hardly ever do so now in any other way than flying. The Indian Agents of The Pas and Prince Albert, the former one especially, and the Medical Superintendent of The Pas Agency, Dr. Yule, would be ready witnesses to this fact and to the conclusion that it is absolutely out of the question now to have the Indians bring their children by canoe for days and weeks of travel.

Your financial aid in this respect, which amounted to $1500.00 for last year and the year before, was great help, since it covered about half of the total expenses. Since our own financial condition is worsening with the years, and since we were not included in the last augmentation of the per capita grant, may we hope this year to receive a still greater compensation for our air travel expenses on account of the children.

I am leaving the whole thing to your sympathetic understanding of our conditions, and dare believe that we may see once more the effect of your devoted consideration,

Yours very truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Principal.
OTTAWA, December 23rd, 1948.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: Transportation accounts for the Children of Guy Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

You will find attached transportation accounts for the Children of the Guy Indian Residential School for the year 1948. These accounts comprise the expenses incurred last June and September. We hope that they will be paid in full, if it is at all possible to do so.

I agree with what you have told me on several occasions regarding air transportation expenses in general, but I doubt if it applies in the present case. Last summer, I visited the Guy School for the first time and noticed the total absence of roads in that part of Manitoba and Saskatchewan. His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse had to charter a special plane for my visit, at the cost of $600.00. I admit that I thought the charges were excessive but I was informed that the owner of the plane was undercharging all competitors for my trip. I therefore know that amounts paid by the principal of the Guy School are reasonable and should be accepted by the Department.

Schools which have no transportation difficulties are certainly advantaged when compared to schools like the Guy, as the full grant can then be applied for the maintenance of the Institution.

Wishing you the compliments of the season,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, o.m.i.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,

September the 18th, 1940

Mr. Eric Law,
Supt Indian Agency,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir,

I have received this week without any accompanying letter most of the Applications for Admission which you were returning to me. There had been indeed quite a mistake on my part when I sent you these forms. What happened is this: I had set one copy of every form apart from the other two I wanted to send to you, and I put in the envelope the wrong pile of papers. The ones I sent you were the less complete, and that is why I wanted to keep them for myself.

The same thing happened to the forms I sent to Prince Albert. Since they are asking for all three forms over there, I think I might as well send you all I have also regarding the children of your agency; so with the contents of this envelope and what you have already on hand, you should find three copies of all applications for admission. In many cases I received only one copy from the Reserves, and even then it did not always bear all the required signatures.

I deeply regret this extra work my mistake has entailed for you.

Yours very truly,

Sgd. Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,

The Pas, Manitoba,

I am enclosing herewith 22 Applications for Admission to the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan.

Also in several instances the duplicate copy is forwarded, as these copies contained the most information to complete same. I also enclose copy of Father Polrier's letter to Mr. Law explaining reason for this and trust that they will be accepted by the Department.

Mr. Law is at present on holidays and will not be returning until October 3rd and I did not wish to hold these up until his return. Mr. Law signed duplicates of these applications which did not have the parents signature and were returned for that reason.

Report concerning AIR TRAVEL EXPENSES for children
of the Guy Indian Residential School to and from their homes.

In 1941, when for the first time accounts were submitted to the Indian Affairs Branch for aeroplane transportation of children to and from school for their holidays, it aroused much surprise at Ottawa, and the hope was expressed by them that such expenditures would not have to be repeated. To the contrary, and notwithstanding the desire of the school authorities to avoid expenses that the Department would not approve and the payment of which it would not share, the air travel expenses for children have been steadily increasing from year to year, and while the accounts of 1941 showed the amount of $125.00, the accounts of 1946 are showing the staggering figure of $325.00. The Indian Affairs Branch will evidently and rightly look for an explanation; I shall try to give it by presenting the history of children transportation to this school, and comparing the present system of transportation with the other alternatives.

* * * * *

- Location of the school,
- Canoe travelling,
- Such travelling was made for other reasons than children:

Sturgeon Landing, Sask., was proposed as a good location for an Indian Residential School in the 1920s: it was certainly at the time a very reasonable choice. Sturgeon Landing was not indeed close to any of the Reserves it was intended to serve, but it was situated on the main road leading to all those reserves; Sturgeon Landing was truly then the Gateway of the North.

From Pelican Narrows, South Reindeer Lake, Pakitawagan, canoes came every summer to get the supplies of the fur companies; those canoe trips were not then any shorter nor easier than they are now. From 100 to 400 miles one way, up and down rivers strewn with rapids, over long or steep or swampy portages numbering as many as forty on one trip, across lakes where wind and furious waves would hold them often for days on the shore, stormed by mosquitoes or drenched by heavy rains with only a light tent for protection, sweating by day and freezing by night, the Indian travellers bravely carried on their task of taking to the northern posts the supplies of the Hudson's Bay Company or other companies, on which depended their living for the following winter.

Those freighters worked thus all summer and thought nothing of it because it was their livelihood; without those goods they would have nothing from the stores in the winter, and besides, they were paid for this canoe freighting. Therefore it was not asking too much of the Indians to add their children to the load in June and to bring them in their empty canoes in August. As long as they were given food supplies for the kids, they were just glad because their travelling expenses and their time were paid for from other sources anyhow.

Very often indeed did the children arrive at school sick, after such trips where so much depends on the weather. When an Indian is travelling with his family, wife and children, he is not as a rule in a hurry and whenever weather threatens, they pitch the tent and make everything comfortable as they can for the children, ready to wait until good conditions prevail; when men are travelling for freight, it is different; they do not like to stop unless it is really tough, because they are not usually supplied with food for any more than the average time required for this trip, and if they stop too long they will starve, and this happened more than once.
So hardship often resulting in sickness was encountered in those trips, and a great number of sick and dead during the first ten years of the school might well be traced back to those hardships of travel.

Such were in 1926 the transport "facilities" -if it is not mockery to call them so- for the children of the Guy School of Sturgeon Landing. In the circumstances they were indeed facilities, as experience was to prove.

-Change of conditions with building of railway:

At the same time the school was being built in 1925-26, a much bigger enterprise was heading North, and that was to spell the end of Sturgeon Landing as the Gateway of the North. Flin Flon was developing and a railway was being built from The Pas to the new mining camp, soon to be a town; it was passing twenty-three miles east of the school and the only access to it in summer was (and pretty well is yet) a difficult canoe route of thirty miles. If the actual developments of this region could have been foreseen then, it is doubtful whether Guy School would have been erected where it stands now.

The new railway opened up Flin Flon and Sherridon, bringing to an end the water transportation between The Pas and Sturgeon Landing, and between this place and the northern posts. The hitherto "facilities" of transportation described above vanished with the settlement and very few families of Indians and Halfbreeds were all that was left in Sturgeon Landing besides the school.

The water route of long ago always remained opened from Sturgeon Landing north, but who was to use it when there was no more freight to get and no retribution for the hardwork of the trip? And soon there was to be no summer freight at all for the Indians, as the tractors from the mining centres were to reach all the Indian settlements of the region on winter roads.

From Pelican Narrows, South End and North Reindeer Lake (Brochet) some Indians still volunteered to come as far as Sturgeon Landing for their children, but already the school had to pay more in food and other help to make sure that the Indians would keep coming. While there was no more freight from Sturgeon Landing, there was also work now in the North for the Indians who cared to work and the men would not undertake weeks of canoe travel without pay just for the sake of taking their children to school.

From Pakitawagan the railroad provided some help to cover a great part of the distance. But Sturgeon Landing is 30 miles by water from the railroad and Pakitawagan from Sherridon is a two day canoe trip when conditions are at their very best: the wind on Cold Lake has often stopped the canoes for days at a time, and the same thing happened between the railroad and Sturgeon Landing on Goose Lake. So it meant organizing a flotilla of canoes from the school to the railroad and make sure that another flotilla would be at the other end of the rail to receive them, while there was no accommodation in Cold Lake for the children. It was even worse when the children were coming back: there had to be somebody from the school waiting for the children in Cold Lake (Sherridon) while a group of men and canoes had to wait at Goose Lake for an indefinite number of days. Everything taken into account, there was hardly anything to gain with the railroad.

So from all sides the expenses, time and trouble gone into for the transportation of the children, the dissatisfaction of the Indians and the dangers of all kinds for the pupils, the consequently increasing difficulties of recruiting, everything definitely called for a change and the plane was all indicated.
First plane trips,
Canoe vs plane:

The first plane trips for children were made in June 1940. In August many children came back by air too. This first trial proved satisfactory and in 1941 a few more trips were made, the accounts of which aroused the Department at the time.

An account in the thousand dollars for transportation of children had likely not been seen yet at the Indian Affairs, except maybe in the form of payment for the purchase of busses or trucks used for gathering up children or taking them home in some other schools.

The expense was startling at first sight, but further exploration of the question would show that the expense was not at all a new item nor a new figure in the list of disbursements. "Transportation" be it air transportation or other kind, had always been a burden to the school, especially since the canoe freighting had stopped; the 75 or 100 dollars contributed yearly by the Branch specifically for the transportation of children was never more than a token retribution compared to the real expenses incurred therein, in the form of wages, gasoline, motors and canoes, food and clothing, a decreasing enrolment and the plain loss of children through sickness, some of those and other items not to be counted in dollars and cents.

Right now it is generally admitted in this part of the country that to travel far the plane is still the cheapest way, -and the Indians themselves widely use it.

There are not here, like in other northern regions great water routes to afford easy and cheap communications from one place to the other. To make sure of that, I did not only look at the maps of the country, but since I have been appointed principal of this school, I have been out two summers, more than a month altogether, to go by canoe into all but one of the reserves our children come from, and the description I have attempted above of the country and of canoe travelling is not only hearsay: it is sheer experience. I could have made the same trips by plane with less expense and in a much easier way, but then I would not have felt confident enough to present this plea in favor of plane transportation for our children.

Increasing accounts and why:

The aeroplane accounts have been going up though since the start, and this is due to several causes:
1/ the rates of the flying companies have been raised;
2/ their conditions have become onerous, v.g., as not to take so many children as before in one aircraft, or refusing to make charter trips between regular schedule stops;
3/ the proportion of children from places cared for by air has increased, so as to be the near totality now: 103 this last August; so that higher fares and more children from far are the only explanation of the later accounts.

Contributions of the Branch:

The contribution of the Indian Affairs Branch to the transportation of children since the plane is used has been increasing too, as these figures show:

| Year | Amount |
|------|--------|
| 1941 | $100.00 |
| 1942 | $150.00 |
| 1943 | $450.00 |
| 1944 | $550.00 |

The better interests of the school and of the Indians were evidently seen and I again take the opportunity to thank very sincerely the officers of the branch for their more generous help in these later years.
Great sacrifices though have still to be made by the school or the church authorities who pay the major part of the children transportation. It is that much money that can not be spent otherwise for the benefit of the children but with a school only half full the school finances would be still in a worse position.

Conclusion and request:

All governments insist so much nowadays on education that the actual opportunities of Guy School ought not to be left unemployed for lack of adequate means of transportation. The reason for plane transportation I hope I have made clear enough, and if Guy School is to remain opened to Indian children I beseech the authorities of the Indian Affairs Branch not to oppose this way of doing, which was forced upon us by circumstances herein explained.

If this report may cause the Indian Affairs Branch officials to admit and even to approve, it is hoped, the actual method of transportation of children to Guy School, may they have the Branch assume a greater part if not all of the payment of the said transportation. The consequences of such a move, may they rest assured, would be all to the benefit of the children themselves whose welfare they so earnestly desire.

Rev. L. Poirier,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

re Cecilia Jebb and Michael Jebb,
Application for admission.

You will find herewith the Application for Admission of Cecilia and Michael Jebb, sister and brother of Therese Jebb, already in this school, #0274, 13 yrs old.

The mother of these children, herself a former pupil of this school, has asked us to take care of her children while she has been called for a stay in the Sanatorium. Cecilia is old enough to go to class and will likely stay with us even after her mother's recovery.

Michael being too young will be returned to his mother if and when she goes back home. Though Michael's form is not completed on the Physical Examination side, he has been taken in the school only with the consent of our Medical Superintendent, Dr. R.F. Yule.

Doctor Yule however has not deemed necessary to fill in the form since he thinks that the little boy's stay will only be temporary.

Since the school is not quite full to capacity, I nevertheless ask the Indian Affairs Branch to officially admit Michael Jebb, so that he may be included in the Quarterly Return for the per capita allowance.

If it is your advice, I shall have the form normally completed at the next visit of the Doctor.

Yours truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Principal.

Dear Sir,

I am submitting herewith to your examination the two accounts we had to pay this summer in order to send the children home for their holidays and get them back here.

Last year I sent with the accounts a detailed explanation of the conditions which make necessary for us these abnormally big transportation expenses. On the total amount then of $3,225.00 the Indian Affairs Branch has refunded to us the sum of $1,500.00, for which I was most grateful.

The conditions which asked for these expenses have not changed, and therefore I submit these new accounts, which have already been paid by the R.C. Episcopal Corporation at The Pas, with the hope that a similar help may be extended to us once more. And why not express openly my confidence that eventually, through your sympathetic understanding of our difficulties, the Department will himself absorb more and more the payment of this extraordinary expenditure.

You will note that we have been able to carry a few passengers other than school children on these chartered trips and this has helped us to a certain amount.

in Aug. 1,660.00
3,235.00

Aug 387.70

April the 3rd, 1948

Mr. Philip Phelan,
Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir,

I received last night the telegram advising me that the accounts I sent to the Department last fall, concerning the transportation of pupils, had not reached you.

I am therefore sending you new copies both of my letter at the time and of the accounts. I have added a voucher as requested. The fact that you require these copies assure me that our case is being considered and is in good hands.

I regret that the loss of the first accounts may be giving you more work, but I hope you will be able yet to help us.

Thanking you in advance,

I remain yours truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Principal.

Indian Affairs Branch,

Attention: B.F. Neary

Dear Sir:

Guy Indian Residential School Quarterly Report for quarter ending September 30th enclosed. Please note, that the 35 pupils marked truant, are listed as being in residential quarters for 46 days. I might add that these children did not return to school this term, and are on their Reserves.

As all children went home this summer for June and July, returning August 15th, I cannot see how it can be stated that the school quarter has 92 days in it. The Principal of the school is away at present and will not return for sometime, so this matter cannot be taken up with him.

I have signed this report but would appreciate advice as to how the first column in attendance section on this form is made up.

Your obedient servant,

E. Law,
Supt. Indian Agency.
OTTAWA, November 13th, 1948.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: Duration of School Year at the Guy Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

Reverend Father L. Poirier, O.M.I., Principal of the above school, says in a letter received today that the children of this school left for their homes by plane, on the 14-15-16th of June. The children returned on the 16th and 17th of August, as the 15th fell on a Sunday.

Strictly speaking, it may be said that the children left on the 16th of June and returned on the 16th of August which would constitute the two months of vacation which they are allowed on the school reports. The leaving date was put down as June the 15th and the returning date was the 15th of August.

Reverend Father Poirier says that the Department wrote to him last year to find out why summer vacations were allowed on the dates mentioned above and adds that his answer to your letter must have been found satisfactory as neither your agent or your office wrote again about the subject.

Hoping that the above explanation will be found satisfactory,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, O.M.I.
November 23, 1948.

Mr. E. Law,
Superintendent,
Indian Agency,
The Pas, Manitoba.

We have received your letter of October 15th with reference to the September quarter return of the Guy Residential School.

Please note that the return requires the principal to show the number of days in the quarter. That means that on the March quarter return he shows 90 days, on the June quarter 91 days, on the September quarter 92 days and on the December quarter 92 days.

The return as prepared by the principal was correct. Attached is a copy of a circular letter regarding the preparation of the quarterly return and I would also direct your attention to the instructions contained on the quarterly return form.

Philip Phelan
Chief, Education Division.

Attention: Mr. Philip Phelan.

Dear Sir,

Once more I am coming to you with quite a big bill of expense for the transportation of our children last summer. Though the number of children has increased at the school re-opening, I have been able to manage so that the air travel accounts did not increase in proportion.

Air travel is becoming ever more common in this part of the country, so much that the Indians themselves coming out to the railroad hardly ever do so now in any other way than flying. The Indian Agents of The Pas and Prince Albert, the former one especially, and the Medical Superintendent of The Pas Agency, Dr. Yule, would be ready witnesses to this fact and to the conclusion that it is absolutely out of the question now to have the Indians bring their children by canoe for days and weeks of travel.

Your financial aid in this respect, which amounted to $1500.00 for last year and the year before, was great help, since it covered about half of the total expenses. Since our own financial condition is worsening with the years, and since we were not included in the last augmentation of the per capita grant, may we hope this year to receive a still greater compensation for our air travel expenses on account of the children.

I am leaving the whole thing to your sympathetic understanding of our conditions, and dare believe that we may see once more the effect of your devoted consideration,

Yours very truly,

Rev. L. Poirier, C.M.,

Principal.

Attention: Mr. P. Phelan.
Re: Transportation accounts for the Children of Guy Indian Residential School.

Dear Mr. Phelan:

You will find attached transportation accounts for the Children of the Guy Indian Residential School for the year 1948. These accounts comprise the expenses incurred last June and September. We hope that they will be paid in full, if it is at all possible to do so.

I agree with what you have told me on several occasions regarding air transportation expenses in general, but I doubt if it applies in the present case. Last summer, I visited the Guy School for the first time and noticed the total absence of roads in that part of Manitoba and Saskatchewan. His Excellency Bishop Lajeunesse had to charter a special plane for my visit, at the cost of $600.00. I admit that I thought the charges were excessive but I was informed that the owner of the plane was undercharging all competitors for my trip. I therefore know that amounts paid by the principal of the Guy School are reasonable and should be accepted by the Department.

Schools which have no transportation difficulties are certainly advantaged when compared to schools like the Guy, as the full grant can then be applied for the maintenance of the Institution.

Wishing you the compliments of the season,

I remain,

Yours very truly,

J. O. Plourde, o.m.i.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,

Mr. Eric Law,
Supt Indian Agency,
The Pas, Man.

Dear Sir,

I have received this week without any accompanying letter most of the Applications for Admission which you were returning to me. There had been indeed quite a mistake on my part when I sent you these forms. What happened is this: I had set one copy of every form apart from the other two I wanted to send to you, and I put in the envelope the wrong pile of papers. The ones I sent you were the less complete, and that is why I wanted to keep them for myself.

The same thing happened to the forms I sent to Prince Albert. Since they are asking for all three forms over there, I think I might as well send you all I have also regarding the children of your agency; so with the contents of this envelope and what you have already on hand, you should find three copies of all applications for admission. In many cases I received only one copy from the Reserves, and even then it did not always bear all the required signatures.

I deeply regret this extra work my mistake has entailed for you.

Yours very truly,

Sgd. Rev. L. Poirier, G.M.I.
Rev. L. Poirier, O.M.I.,
Principal.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Canada.

I am enclosing herewith 22 Applications for Admission to the Guy Indian Residential School at Sturgeon Landing, Saskatchewan.

There are four of these applications which have not been witnessed, no witness being available. Also in several instances the duplicate copy is forwarded, as these copies contained the most information to complete same. I also enclose copy of Father Poirier's letter to Mr. Law explaining reason for this and trust that they will be accepted by the Department.

Mr. Law is at present on holidays and will not be returning until October 3rd and I did not wish to hold these up until his return. Mr. Law signed duplicates of these applications which did not have the parents signature and were returned for that reason.

Q. P. Jackson
for E. Law,

With further reference to the boy, John Baptiste Dentouzie, referred to in my letter of the 24th instant, File 2279-25-2-171, enclosed is copy of a letter received from Mr. L.D. Ward, Assistant, Indian Agency, Stoney Rapids, Saskatchewan, of the Athabasca Indian Agency, in connection with this boy.

It would appear that there is a possibility that the information which Mr. Davis had obtained regarding the boy was incorrect, as he was informed that the father and mother left the boy, and that the father had since died. The information in Mr. Ward's letter is to the effect that the step-father and mother of the boy about whom Mr. Ward is writing, are both living at Stoney Rapids, but the step-father refuses to let the boy live with them. Assuming that this is correct, I would recommend that the Department take steps to have the necessary instructions go to Mr. Ward that he insist upon the mother and step-father supporting the boy, as the boy's mother's marriage to an Indian of another band gave her the right to live at the home of her husband, and certainly should not deprive her child of the same privilege.

Reference Departmental letter 655-10 (E.6) of August 23rd re: increase of pupilage for the Guy Indian Residential School. I am enclosing a letter received from Rev. Father Poirier outlining available dormitory space. It will readily be seen that space will not allow for an increase in the number of pupils based on the minimum requirements of 500 cu.ft. per pupil.

Father Poirier has recently advised this office he has 156 children in residence, a number of whom were sent in by the parents from distant points unsolicited by Father Poirier. The children mentioned came in by plane from the Brochet area, and as stated by Father Poirier, the plane was not returning to Brochet, consequently, he had no alternative but to keep the children.

I am sure satisfactory arrangements will be made by the staff at this school to accommodate these additions. It is my intention to visit the Residential School at Sturgeon Landing in the near future at which time I intend to make a thorough inspection of the dormitories. If I find that the sleeping quarters are over-crowded and the children cannot be accommodated adequately, I will immediately report to this effect on my return.

Please refer to this office letter dated September 24th, 1949, File 2279-25-2-171, and reply from the Department dated September 29th, File 655-10 (El),

After some considerable correspondence between this office and Mr. L.D. Ward, Assistant, Indian Agency, Stoney Rapids, it was decided that the only thing which could be done was to place the boy, John Baptiste Dentouzie, in the Beauval School. The boy was sent to the Beauval School by plane, and arrived there on December 22nd, 1949.

Reverend Father F.X. Gagnon, O.M.I., Principal of the School, is now enquiring about the completion of the necessary forms of application for admission to the school.

If it is necessary to have application forms completed by the mother of the boy, the forms should be sent to Mr. L.D. Ward for completion. However, it is hoped that it will be possible to have the boy taken on the strength of the Beauval School as a grant earning pupil without completion of the papers, as I believe that Mr. Ward may have some considerable difficulty in getting the forms completed.

Please instruct me in this connection. It will be noted that the boy is a member of the Barren Land's Band (Manitoba). There was some considerable difficulty in identifying the boy when the matter was first brought to my attention by Mr. Ward, and although it is now disclosed that he is a Manitoba Indian child, I presume it is as well for the completion of the formal admission of the boy to the Beauval School to be carried out through this office. I shall await the Department's instructions in the matter.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.

Dear Sir:

With regard to my Christmas Present, John Baptiste Dentouzie, I just got a letter from Father Darveau, from Brochet, Man., stating John Baptiste's Guardian is reclaiming the boy this summer. The Guardian's name is Louis Deneganaze, from Brochet.

I do not know if you have any objection to let John Baptiste have his Summer holidays and may be let him have the choice to go to Sturgeon Landing School, as he will be with his own band there.

As for me, it will be very hard to keep him this Summer as the brother in charge of the boys will take a well deserved holiday. So I would prefer not to keep him during the Summer.

For your information, I am very glad to report that John Baptiste is doing very fine here and is now getting along very good with the other boys. He is fond of hockey and ball, but unfortunately he is unable to play at the present time. He has sore feet. If he does not get well soon, I will have to take him to the hospital.

Regarding his plane fare to Brochet, I suppose the Department will take care of that?

On May 19th, the school children will give a concert at 3.30 P.M. for the patients in the San, C.K.B.I. will broadcast it and they mention "It is very good".

Hoping for the best in the next future.

Yours very truly, Sgd. F.X. Gagnon, Principal.

Please refer to Department Letter dated February 7th, 1950, File 655-10 (EL), regarding John Baptiste Dentouzie, who was placed in the Beauval Indian Residential School on December 22nd, 1949.

Enclosed is copy of a letter today received from Reverend Father F.X. Gagnon, O.M.I., Principal of the Beauval Indian Residential School. Father Gagnon reports that he has received a letter from Father Darveau, Missionary at Brochet, Manitoba, stating that John Baptiste Dentouzie's guardian is reclaiming the boy this summer. The guardian's name is Louis Deneganaze, of Brochet.

At the urgent request of Mr. L.D. Ward, Assistant, Indian Agency, Stony Rapids, the boy was placed in the Beauval School, as Mr. Ward stated that the boy's mother and stepfather refused to keep him, and it was considered necessary for his welfare to place him in an Indian residential school.

At that time it was practically impossible to have the boy placed in the Guy School, at Sturgeon Landing, as there was no plane transportation direct between the two points, and there was no other method of travel.

As it now appears from Father Gagnon's letter that Louis Deneganaze is an uncle of the boy, and is willing to accept responsibility for him, I think the boy should be returned by plane to Brochet to be in charge of Louis Deneganaze, and not returned to the Beauval School for the beginning of the next term. If he is to attend residential school it would be better for him to be admitted to the Guy Indian Residential School, at Sturgeon Landing.

It will be noted that.....
It will be noted that Father Gagnon advises it will be difficult to keep the boy at the Beauval School for the summer as the brother in charge of the boys will be away for a holiday, and there will be no one to take care of him. He was reported to be very difficult to handle, and was so when first admitted to the Beauval School, but has not given much trouble recently.

I would recommend that the Department approve sending the boy by plane from Beauval to Brochet, at the expense of the Department, and that a telegram be sent direct to Reverend Father Gagnon from the Department authorizing the same.

J.P.B. Ostrander,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies,
Saskatchewan.
